The last part of getting the best ending entails the game going balls to the wall hard with one of the difficult segments of a platformer I've played in awhile. I played with the original graphics and music, mind you, but the new graphics and music aren't bad. It was really fun the whole way through, so all in all I'd say it's a pretty badass game.

150047645.review:
(Warning: I'm not sure how well are Nicalis practices as a publisher. I'm reviewing Cave Story+ as a game, but I implore you to research about Nicalis before buying this. Should you disagree, download the freeware verson)

Cave Story is an indie classic and for good reason. It's not about its impressive graphics or insanely outlandish gameplay. It's the grandfather of indie games for having a good idea, executing it very well and being developed by a small studio (in this case, one guy). Cave Story is a 2D platformer run'n'gun with a very neat story, soundtrack, gameplay, ambience and overall feel. It's just a game that feels good to play. Everything about its main game is charming and I can't recommend it enough.

I only have one small issue with the game with the game (mild spoilers ahead): 
[spoiler] The entirety of the good ending route. [/spoiler] 


[spoiler] Everything from the game's normal and bad ending are super cohesive. Gameplay is balanced, story is well paced and well laid out in your path. Nothing feels out of place. But the good ending requirements ask you to do some asenine weird logic for its completion, it undermines the well written main villain with a bigger out of nowhere bad guy and the balancing of the last act is hellish. The neutral ending was super memorable, emotional and narratively relevant, but the good ending, while it's nice the idea of having a happy ending, comes at the cost of narrative coherence and frustrating gameplay. [/spoiler] 

Even with the previous issue about it, I can easily say it's one of the best games I have played and I don't regret playing it at all. It's definitely worth experiencing it, although if you do, it may be worth using a guide for the aforementioned issue if you don't feel like handling that specific hassle

149473042.review:
It may not be for every modern gamer, but it's my favorite platformer. I've played it for years, and the steam version adds some good features such as achievements.

Pros:
+ the weapons — The variety and usefulness of their mechanics is often what keeps me coming back to this game.
+ slowly discoverable story — I enjoy figuring out chronology and answers to questions such as where various characters came from. However I wish the dialogues could be viewed and dismissed instantly instead of scrolling.
+ multiple paths — There are more possible turns in the game than first appears, with drastically varying difficulties, which you can get an idea of by looking at the achievements. I also like how unexpected things happen in the story, like a character must die no matter how you try to save them.
+ bosses — These are my idea of what traditional boss fights should be.
+ pure keyboard controls — I get tired of games that require a mouse, and the keys feel tight and responsive.
+ graphics — Similar to the last point, the graphics are simple and won't give you motion sickness, yet they can still be beautiful at times.

Cons:
- unintuitive at times — Following the best track may require talking to or ignoring a certain character, and these are often game-changing decisions that cannot be reversed. I sometimes read guides to find out the results of different choices.
- difficulty and repetition — I'm not sure if this is good or bad, but I often think that it would be more fun if areas such as the upgraded last cave weren't so hard or tedious. Save points can be very far between. However, if it weren't for these things, then winning would not feel as fulfilling.
- dialogue scrolling, as mentioned above

149236876.review: A classic platform adventure from a fleeting gilded era of once-freeware retro indie games, including Spelunky, La Mulana, Hydorah and others, which is not quite like anything else, but smacks of a lot of things. 149162881.review:
Cave Story. A beautiful yet challenging game featuring two of my favorite characters Quote and Curly (Brace).

I played on easy at first and wondered why Quote was orange/yellow, but I eventually switched to original and it was all good. The art style is charming and the soundtracks were quite lively (especially Bushlands, Sandzone and Plantation/Main Menu). The diversity of weapons is also neat as it allows for multiple playstyles according to the player, and it rewards skillful playing by letting you upgrade your weapons and keep them powered up. And sure, some of the bosses and what not could have been better/more balanced, including the final spoiler boss which has no saves on your way to him. But honestly, most of what I'd say about how I play or what I struggle with is all in my honest opinion.

Edit: After getting the true ending with Curly, I can safely say that I've improved quite a lot as I first tried the spoiler boss at the end. It's all about learning a moveset and adapting to change. And I am happier now that I've gotten the true ending with both characters!

One last thing is that I may never forget this game, ever! And if I ever did, I would actually cry/sob.


[i] "Dear Curly and Quote,

     The very first day we met was a rather blissful day at that dead-end cave. And the fact that you stayed with me for so long and helped me through these obstacles. How you saved me from drowning and serviced me properly after the fact. When you earned my Tungsten Trust by being so caring and understanding. And when you convinced me that there is still a fight to win, despite me feeling like all was lost...

I have unfinished business back at home, at the very same company who tried to kill me and who created the "Scout Killers". I trust you with all levels of my tungsten and xenon body, and I also trust that you will follow me through to the other side of that teleporter. I hope to see you on the other side, to help me defeat the one who started this all... [/i]


    Sincerely,

Swifter Roughlead

148276582.review:
7.5/10
Aaaa Bloodstained sanctuary, it buurns. Probably 1/4 of the time playing the game was spent on the last 'road to the best ending' segment, which made me a bit angrier and my opinion a bit lower

Jumped into this game mostly blindly. Kind of a weird one, featuring many flaws of the past era games. 
Minuses:
- Bad placement of savepoints - repeating progress could feel painful
- Random difficulty spikes
- Unskippable dialogue\cutscenes (annoying at bosses and probs at game reruns)
- Traversing long locations in different directions was not  fun.
- Losing weapon EXP when taking damage is a horrible mechanic, imo.
- Story that starts in a "Random bullsh*t go!" style and is only getting explained much later on
- Story in general lacks depth. Its not too bad, but is told kinda fast... slow moments and 'juicy details' would be appreciated
- Best ending and some characters lives being decided by a very unpredictable and stupid player choice in the mid-game (almost impossible to make unknowingly)
- Best ending is additionally locked by an extremely hard sequence of levels near the end. And then its story ends up being not that special or satisfying >.<

Pluses:
+ Interesting\charming, at times.
+ Dynamic platforming gameplay (haven't expected it)
+ Difficulty is satisfying, at times. (delete Bloodstained sanctuary pls)
+ A bunch of weapons and all are useful in some way, wow
+ While many music tracks were kind of "ok but forgettable", some were really cool (Labyrinth Fight, Meltdown 2, Scorching Back, Moonsong, Pressure)

Overall... I probably got forked into this one from Undertale recommendations. They are somewhat similar in terms of story, both being fantasy tales. Imo - Undertale overrides this game in almost all aspects, specifically so at story and characters, all of which were much deeper. But, in terms of gameplay, Undertale fights also felt more memorable. Mhm. Anyway, Cave story is a nice platformer, and, given its date of creation (2004), its pretty damn great. For me, it's likely better than Ori, but loses to Hollow Knight and Celeste.

¡Vaya joya de juego es "Cave Story"! Te lo digo de corazón, este título es una verdadera joya de la industria. Desde el momento en que conoces a Quote, el protagonista, y a Curly Brace, sientes una conexión instantánea con estos queribles personajes que te acompañarán en toda tu aventura.

La historia que se desarrolla en las profundidades de la caverna es simplemente atrapante. Cada encuentro y revelación te mantiene enganchado de principio a fin. La dificultad avanzada del juego es un reto que te impulsa a mejorar constantemente, y créeme, cuando superas esos desafíos, la satisfacción es inigualable.

Las peleas con los jefes son épicas, cada una es única y te obliga a idear estrategias diferentes para vencerlos. No puedo evitar mencionar los tres finales, ¡son realmente interesantes y te hacen replantearte tus decisiones en el juego!

En resumen, "Cave Story" es un must-play para cualquier amante de los videojuegos. Si buscas una experiencia que combine personajes entrañables, una trama cautivante, desafío y una variedad de finales sorprendentes, este juego es para ti. ¡No puedo recomendarlo lo suficiente!

144916515.review:
Decent game plagued by a ton of either archaic or bad game design decisions.

The game doesn't give you any hints towards "how" to accomplish the good ending, just that there's a way to save a specific person. The way you are supposed to get there is filled with "did you do this specific thing" checks that are horribly un-intuitive. If you talk to a specific NPC at a specific time, you're locked out of it kind of un-intuitive.

There's no cutscene skip function, and no text skip option. You can't turn off specific visual effects (which actually only bothered me at the end of the game.) There's also a very specific part of the game which was patched in the switch version that turns the most fetchquesty part of the game into a more streamlined experience, unfortunately it wasn't put in this version for some reason.

I have to give it a 6/10. Would easily be an 8 if the design problems were fixed.

This is definitely one of those games where you'd want to play it twice. Once for the normal ending, and once for the good ending. The normal route is what you'd likely do on your first playthrough anyway.

If you want to play this on a huge monitor you need to override the high dpi scaling, on Windows 10 you would right click the exe -> Compatibility -> Change High DPI Settings -> Check Override and set dropdown menu to Application

141021503.review: Cave Story; My gaming magnum opus. Doukutsu Monogatari is my favorite game of all time, ever since 2015 when I first played CS DSiWare, And then beat CS WiiWare. Cave Story has incredible charm and cute characters, yet a story that always keeps you engaged. It shows the struggles of war, and even how those not involved with war are affected. It shows that power leads to madness. It is a brilliant example of crafting brilliance out of graphical limitations. The 8-16-32 bit style graphics may be limiting, yet they never feel limited in the slightest, each character feels real, and human. The decisions to be made, and the constant arsenal of weapons allowing no play-through to be truly the same. All, with music written by the brilliant Amaya-San. I cannot recommend this game enough, but I will try to. 100/10. Pure Brilliance.

140793758.review:
One of the most impactful platform adventure games ever created, and was responsible for the rekindling and revolutionizing indie gaming after the end of the C64. The story, characters, environments, and sound direction all hold up nearly twenty years after the original release. Not much to really say. This port, however? I cannot, in good faith, recommend purchasing as it grossly lacks the updates made in the Nintendo Switch release. Most notably the crushingly difficult, yet still fun co-op mode. Aside from that, the Switch release added pretty effects for lighting, water, and many other things.

This version of CS+ was novel for a time, but it doesn't make sense to buy or play this version anymore since you can easily find free source ports that are on content parity with the Switch version.

I was looking forward to playing this game and in spite of me procrastinating on playing Cave Story i finally decided to play it, knowing the reputation of how good this game was, it still suprised me to see the love that pixel put in this game.

The gameplay is a great mix of exploration with a seasoning of metroidvania, with solid combat and enemy variety, all the guns are fun to use and although some are showcased a little too late in the game to be useful they all still are a blast to use!

The character writing is on par with other games like Undertale and has definetly got me to play much more of the game by the characters alone.

The story is also very well written and engaging, although it's a slow burn at first, but once it clicks, and it will, you'll enjoy the game a lot!

The game's difficulty depending on what route you are going for will range from easy and fun to challenging and unrelenting, it really suprised me how when i was going for the true ending I was put through a really hard gauntlet of platforming challenges, I did enjoy the challenge by the end!


If you plan on buying or wishlisting this game i am begging you play this with as less spoilers about it as possible, the less the better! 

For a rating the game deserves a "wtf I love Cave Story now??" out of 10

136222397.review:
A exemplar of what indie gaming is all about.

Pixel's masterwork [i]Cave Story [/i]features an engaging story, great art, lovable characters, and smooth platforming: four characteristics made all the more impressive when you consider that it originally came out in 2004. What the game does well is market itself to all skill levels: if you want a more casual experience, you can do an easy playthrough collecting all health upgrades. For those who want to truly immerse themselves in the Cave Story experience, there's hard mode, which is as brutally true to its name as any difficulty ramp I've ever seen. I was first exposed to this game when I was in elementary school, and the varying difficulty levels of achievements to pursue has kept me coming back throughout all the different stages of my gaming journey. 

I'd be proud to call this game one of my all-time favorites. 



"So long as you always maintain a sense of exploration, you will someday find the way out. This is my hope."

131716064.review:
Cave Story is probably one of the earliest internet released indie sensations, that wasn’t a flash game about beating up celebrities, that took the internet by storm; being one of those games that any “gamer” worth his cred should have played at least once. Does this game hold up? Yes. Is it worth buying Cave Story+ instead of just playing the original freeware version?... Well, read on for a more in-depth review of this particular version (port?) of Cave story.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]
Studio Pixel’s art style is very endearing, and honestly just strikes my personal preferences in the right way; it’s both cute and abstract, it leaves room for interpretation and imagination while being immediately clear what everything is at the same time. Unlike so many other indie games that merely try to copy the style of other games, Studio Pixel manages to cut his own style in the medium that is both appealing and immediately identifiable as his work.
Beyond just the quality of his pixel art, Studio Pixel is a pretty great artist/character designer in a general sense.

Of course one of the things Cave Story is most famous for is its music; it’s great. There is very little to say besides that.

[b]Cave Story +[/b]
Cave story+’s visuals are updated, all the sprites and art have been redrawn to 16-bit. The music too has both, been remastered AND remade for this release.

Don’t like Cave Story+’s Art or Music, and prefer the original’s? Just go into the options and change them back. It respects the original’s presentation while offering a different look.

[h1]Writing[/h1]
One of the things I adore about Studio Pixel’s work is his mix of Mature & Immature; The whimsical Fairytale Adventure like Plot, with Cutesy characters (the Immature); with the dark background elements and Death scenes of said Cutesy characters (the Mature). In fact there are some surprisingly “Adult” things in this game that give the characters so much more… character, such as picking up a female character’s underwear as an item, or finding another character’s lipstick in your inventory. It’s suggestive, but in a way that goes over a child’s head.

Anyway, Cave Story is a story of a young mute boy who wakes up in a cave with no memories, thus begins his “Cave Story” if you will… Along the way you’ll meet a village of rabbit people who are under siege by a powerful being called “The Doctor” and his lackeys. The game does a great job of revealing its plot and answering its mysteries piece by piece. 

The world building is great too, with great little background details that say a lot for example: [spoiler]The hero Arthur, the strongest of the rabbit people, inside his house we see the red flowers in the basement, the red flowers being a source of rage inducing power for the rabbit people; the implication is that Arthur used the red flowers to gain his strength but retained control of himself. This is never outright stated, nor even touched upon.[/spoiler]

[b]Cave Story+[/b]
Nothing really changed here, HOWEVER, the translations are different from the original translations.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Honestly the gameplay is the area that has aged the most poorly, in that Cavestory once had a fairly unique gameplay style that has now become somewhat bog standard for indie games; however it was still Cavestory that set that standard.

With that said, Cavestory still feels quite great to play, with very simple controls, large weighty jumps, and a simple combat loop. 

[b]Cave Story +[/b]
Cave Story+ is essentially the same, though it does offer some neat extra challenge modes, as well as a “Curly Mode”, and a piece of cut content called “The Wind Fortress”.
There is also a Hard Mode for the masochistic, and an Easy Mode for babies.

[h1]Criticisms[/h1]
[b]Presentation[/b]

While I have no criticisms for the Original’s presentation, I do have some thought on +’s:
[list]
[*]The remade Art for the most part looks nice, but giving Quote a mouth, or any other character for that matter, was foolish. The Original’s art allowed for interpretation as to how the character may feel during any given scene, but +’s art makes it look like Quote is smiling at all times, even during the more harrowing scenes. It’s really kills the mood
[*]What’s the point of allowing us to change our preferred art style back to the original, if you’re not going to allow it for the Extra Modes?
[*]Some of the character art changes are just bad
[/list]

[b]Writing[/b]

One criticism I can give to the original work is that it SCREAMS for a sequel. Ordinarily leaving the audience wanting more is a good thing, and there is no lingering plot thread that needed to be answered within this game, and yet there is something about it that leaves you unfulfilled (despite being so good).

There’s also just this certain feeling of elements being underutilised, for example; was there any need or reason for Toroko to be The Hero Arthur’s little sister? But this is likely nitpicking an Indie game made as a hobby.

As +’s handling of the writing… As I hinted at earlier, I’m not impressed by their translations, unless I’m misremembering, it appears they made certain plot reveals far more obvious and took some strong liberties with the dialogue. Nothing seemingly too egregious, but it is frustrating when everyone is saying “Hey aren’t you that [spoiler]solider[/spoiler]… never mind”, only for them to reveal later that you were part of the [spoiler]war[/spoiler]… Hardly a plot twist at that point. It also feels more juvenile, though maybe that’s just a personal preference thing.

Also, the writing for “Curly Mode”, or rather her dialogue, comes across as extraordinarily superfluous. Essentially just pointing out the obvious or repeating what others had said, to the point of being obnoxious and annoying rather than as a fun extra mode.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

Honestly, there’s not too much to criticise here:
[list]
[*] Some bosses feel like you have to tank your way through to some extent, this is particularly exacerbated by the weighty jumps that can make it hard to dodge are weave through projectiles
[*] The backtracking (particularly in Sandzone and Grasslands) is a bit much 
[/list]

As for Cave Story+:
[list]
[*]All the challenges are focused around time-trials rather than being gameplay challenges. This is good if you like speedrunning, but that’s a niche and would be boring for most.
[*]While the addition of a hardmode is great, some bosses almost HAVE to be tanked, and hardmode is solely about ensuring you can’t pick up health upgrades, so this makes some bosses go from slightly-challenging normally to nigh-impossible.
[*]I like collecting the achievements for games I love, but half of the achievements for this game are behind not just the time trials, but differing speeds of the time trials, from C tier to S tier. This is a game I’d heavily dissuade anyone from trying to get all the achievements for.
[*]Remember the secret underwear or lipstick I mentioned earlier? Those give achievements now, and make me roll my eyes. Some things should not have achievements.
[*] This game is almost abandon ware. Nicalis are not updating it. The game will crash every time you beat the challenge modes.
[*]As a paid product, the extra modes aren’t enough to boost the rather paltry play time, which will be around 2-4 hours, depending on your play speed.
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This is one of the most beloved indie games of all time for a reason, there’s a personal feeling to it – it’s something no one else but Studio Pixel (a single man) could have made; it oozes personality. Even now it still feels unique and fresh, despite the imitators.

However, Nicalis’ Cave Story+ feels a little half-hearted, like they saw some easy money by re-releasing a beloved property and have now forgotten about it. Get it on special.

Otherwise, I highly recommend everyone play the freeware version at least. It’s a piece of gaming history at the very least.

A peak standard plat-former shooter that capsulizes everything entertaining and rewarding from the genre! 122858738.review:
A solid 2D platformer / metroidvania / shooter. It has aged incredibly well considering this release came out over ten years prior to this review and the original over half a decade before that.

It has a simple yet compelling story with a pretty good remastered soundtrack and neat 2D sprite designs. The game also features the original soundtrack and graphics as options in the settings although I didn't give those a try.

It has a unique weapons system that I cannot immediately think of any other games which share it. Basically, you level up weapons from enemy XP drops (identical to item drops) and taking damage brings down weapon XP (potentially reducing your weapon to the previous level if you lose enough). I found it to be a very interesting system, and I would love to see new iterations of it in modern games (maybe there are and I just am not aware of or recalling them).

I played on normal difficulty despite the game encouraging easy difficulty on the first playthrough for whatever reason. I did not have much trouble going through the main game up until the end (I don't think I died more than 2-3 times in any given area or boss fight before the last cave that precedes the various final bosses). That said, the final gauntlets provide a good challenge while feeling fair. Well mostly (looking at you RNG falling blocks room in the bloodstained sanctuary)... You have to go through 3-4 bosses and/or platforming sections without any saves in between. They feel daunting but are very doable once you learn the platform and boss patterns.

There is unfortunately no option to skip dialogue entirely that I could find (which you really want to do when you are re-running a section multiple times like the endgame areas). However, you can at least fast forward previously played dialogue in that session by spamming the attack button.

There are a LOT of missables, including the best weapons and best ending requirements... I luckily looked through an achievement guide before locking myself out of the best ending and ultimate weapon. And even then there were some things I missed earlier in the game because I had not looked at a guide yet.

Overall, I can definitely see why it has a reputation as a classic indie game, and I am glad to have finally experienced it!

122833155.review:
Pleasant graphics, nice soundtrack, fun gameplay, creative bosses, all around great game.

But why so CRYPTIC?! There are lots of major secrets which just have no indication what so ever on how to achieve, including multiple weapons, items, and even the GOOD ENDINGS, you effectively HAVE to look up these in advance for the game to not permanently screw you over for acting like a normal person instead of performing the weirdest most obscure actions possible while progressing. The game also has a serious habit of making seemingly harmless decisions permanently punish you, for example a character will ask you "Let me look at X items" and if you say yes, you just lost two of your five weapons permanently, or if you don't do a specific chain of secrets before some random boss a major character dies, or if you try to SAVE YOUR FRIEND he dies and you don't get a jetpack, but if you decide not to (there's no hint at all for you to not save him) he LIVES and you get a cool jetpack, what the hell.

All in all, cool game, but impossible to enjoy to the fullest in a blind playthrough because of the game actively punishing you for not having precognition.

120019941.review:
An improved version of the free Cave Story that is available online. This game deserves a lot of props for helping to ignite the retro indie game craze, but as one of the pioneers it does have some dated aspects as well.

As a whole, the game's presentation is really nice, with charming graphics and a memorable soundtrack. The combat is also pretty unique, having you wield weapons that you power up with shards, but that go down in level when you take damage. It rewards good game play and helps heighten the tension. Cave Story pays clear homage to Metroid in various aspects, but also brings its own unique personality.

Where the game takes a bit of a hit is how obtuse getting the true ending is. In this version of the game, the steps you have to take to successfully access the secret final area and the game's hidden bosses are so counterintuitive that you probably won't be able to figure it out without checking a walkthrough. Also, this version of the game has some lingering bugs, like the fact that it crashes any time you go through one of the optional challenge modes.

The frustrating thing is that a further improved version of this game came out on the Switch a couple years back that has improved graphics, the ability to play with a second person, and an extra challenge mode. And yet for whatever reason, those improvements have not been added into this version. That lack of developer support combined with the game's aforementioned unclear path to the full ending does make this game a bit frustrating now in hindsight. However, I still enjoy it enough to overlook those aspects and recommend it, especially for fans of indie games.

Cave Story is a fun time that also has a really challenging end game if you decide to go for its secret path. It's also a short enough game to replay multiple times and try out different weapons. I give it a 7/10

119856899.review:
Considering how positive the reception around this game is, I don't really get most of it. Admittedly the gameplay is pretty good early on, when you're exploring and finding upgrades, but the clunky and slippery platforming was noticeable right from the very beginning, and doesn't improve much even after a double jump upgrade.
The story was building up to something interesting but dropped the ball. I no longer cared about the story after a certain boss fight and what investment I had in this story and possibly interesting setting was now spent.
I kept going because I had put the effort in up to that point, but the lack of save points towards the latter parts of the game is ridiculous. I gave up when the final boss was in fact a boss rush with no saving. The game's upgrade system constantly punishes you by making your weapons ineffective mid combat if you get hit, which you will considering the clunky movement I already mentioned.
Maybe if this was free or back in 2005 when it was first released it was a good game. I could forgive the clunky movement and the lack of save points to a degree. But that doesn't excuse the story dropping the ball, nor forcing a boss rush at the end.
Only buy this game if you like difficult platformers, and even then when it's on sale. There are so many better platformers out there now.

119005817.review:
This is it. This is the OG non-linear indie sidescroller. You may think it was Super Meat Boy or Spelunky or whatever else that proved a beloved cult classic can still be made by one person in a post-Y2K world, but it was actually Cave Story, way back in 2004. I won't even bother reviewing the game as a whole, because if you're here, then chances are you already know or at least heard how good (and hard) it is. Let's just focus on the things that justify the "+" in the title.

Upgraded graphics are definitely the biggest improvement. They shift the game from an 8-bit aesthetic to a 16-bit aesthetic, and with the amount of colors and background layers the upgrade actually makes more sense. The details added by 2x upscaled pixel art are probably a bit controversial (like giving Balrog an anime blush, changing the Doctor's dialogue expression, or completely reworking Toroko's portrait), but overall, they're really good and focus on what's cool about the characters and the world of Cave Story. There's an option to revert to the original graphics, which is cool, but not once did I feel like it.

Audio is... fifty-fifty. There's 3 soundtrack options: original, new and remastered. The "new" soundtrack sucks. It's still remixed from the original songs, but completely misses the feel of the songs and it makes the game feel like a throwaway Google Play Store download. Remastered soundtrack is decent, pretty cool sometimes, but it also loses the impact of the original in other moments. OG OST is still the best one and is filled to the brim with bangers. Final boss theme remains one of the best final boss themes in gaming, period.

Another point of controversy is the new translation. I have to say, most of the time it felt better to me. More professional, avoids typical problems with JP-EN translation and just feels natural all around. However, sometimes there's these small bits that just sounded way cooler in the old translation, like "heavens, that felt good" or "until the day you die, you WILL be my puppet". Also, two fun easter eggs were completely removed in the translation for unknown reasons. Sadly, there's no option to switch to the old translation.

The last new thing are challenges and achievements - more or less the same thing. If you think the base game is hard (counting the best ending of course), then wait 'til you try them. The machine gun challenge is the easiest of the bunch and it's no wonder there's no achievements tied to it, but the rest is crazy. Wind Fortress, the holy grail of Cave Story cut content finally makes an official appearance, and while it hasn't been tied into the story & game map in any way, it doesn't change the fact that it'll really test your skill with Booster 2.0, Spur, Blade, and mercy invincibility abuse. Getting an S rank is insane, as are all of them actually (though I did it, so you can too!) Did you play the original version? Do you remember the title screen change bonus? Now it's an achievement, too! And you can play just the Sacred Grounds straight from the challenges menu, though you get no rockets there! But you'll find that rockets don't really matter that much this far into the game!! And once you've done all these challenges, be prepared for the beast that is hard mode and beating the entire the game without ANY health upgrades, essentially making it a no-hit run past the third boss or so. Yep, it's clear that a lot of what Cave Story+ offers is aimed at the hardened veterans who know this game like the back of their hand. I know I beat the good ending way back when it was still fresh and learning how to get it was something like an urban legend at the time, and I still needed to pump over 36 hours into this version just so I could hone my skill to perfection to obtain the sweet 100% completion. It's hard as steel but the game is so well done, it's never unfair - every mistake is on you alone.

Whether you've been a fan of Cave Story for 18 years or are learning about it just now, this remaster is worth getting. However, given the controversy surrounding Nicalis, I'd recommend getting it on a big sale, maybe even getting it in a less-than-legal way. The original version is completely freeware and it's still out there, you know. No harm done. But in any case, you didn't hear that from me.

(PS: I'm glad CS never got a sequel. This is as complete of a story as they get and continuing it in any way would ruin its impact.)

117543590.review: I've always wanted to play this game, as its one of the indie game classics, so I gave it a shot. The game has a simple, but fun story and characters, which I loved. I enjoyed the majority of my time with it, but every once in a while, the game would throw something at you that felt a little unfair or cheap. I'm fine with hard games, but they should feel fair, and this game doesn't feel fair at times. For example, reducing all of your weapons to their weakest state right as you go into the final area is so incredibly unfair and mean-spirited, and is ultimately what made me quit after countless deaths in that area. I did managed to beat the game by not picking up the booster, as that results in the platforming for the final area being made less brutal, which I did appreciate (I even kept the Mimiga mask on, lol). The booster's controls in general aren't the most responsive, which I could have lived with, as normally it's pretty fun to use, if the final area's platforming didn't have so little room for error. It's a good game, but its has a lot of cracks. Sometimes I can't help but feel like its age is showing, since some of its game design is pretty archaic. This game feels like a NES game, for better and for worse. If you still want to experience the story and see the gameplay, which I recommend, then I suggest you watch a playthrough instead.

116953056.review:
I wish I could recommend this because there is a lot to admire about it, but the save system and inability to skip dialog / scenes makes this more frustrating than it's worth. Bullet-hell bosses aren't my favorite, but to have to fight through a level and then manually progress story dialog before every attempt is so effing annoying. It's a simple thing to include a story-skip function. There's just no excuse for not including it; particularly if you have to traverse a level first, or fight a four-stage boss that resets when you die with dialog in between each stage. 

It's disappointing because the story and characters are great. I think this game is revered because people didn't expect a single-developer, lo-fi indie game to have a deep, engaging story. The weapon leveling system is brilliant; though the sound of the level wedges hitting the ground drove me nuts.

If you have more patience than a monk (or have a save-state hack,) there's a lot of great stuff here. For me, there are lots of less frustrating Metroidvanias out there that I'd rather play instead.

115173301.review:
Cave story is an absolute classic, and is the indie game that started indie games as a genre due to its popularity.
The controls and gameplay can seem a little awkward and slippery at first, but after a couple hours you'll never want them any other way. The weapons you get are all (well, mostly) useful for the entire game, and the concept of collecting doritos to level up your weapon is really unique and well executed. And speaking of the weapons, man are they fun to use. The gameplay is extremely fast paced and the skill ceiling is quite high. Look up bloodstained sanctuary speedruns on youtube for proof.

On top of perfect gameplay, the subdued story compliments the catchy and intense chiptune boss themes.
And speaking of boss themes, the bosses. Yet another great part of the game, each boss is difficult and intense in its own way.
Buy this game if you want to support Nicalis Inc. and have improved graphics. Download it for free online if you want to play the original game as Daisuke Amaya intended. Either way, you'll have a blast.

112702395.review:
Late game, there is a massive difficulty spike - not in actual mechanic difficulty but the fact of zero save points. There is a point where you need to fight four bosses without a single save point where all the previous levels had reasonable save locations as levels went on. Each boss has a different pattern, so you could be doing great with the 1st and 2nd boss but you need to keep doing them over and over again just so you can get to the final boss to learn his pattern. This is deliberate gameplay padding: Not fun and and goes against the rhythm set by the game until this point. I'd change the difficulty to 'easy' (you take 50% less damage), but that's not possible and you need to start the game from scratch - something I'd rather not do considering how much backtracking this game has.

It's a shame since the game looks nice, has nice music (I like the one where you are climbing the tower outside upwards), and fun weapon play. I also don't like is how floaty the character feels which takes me out of the game sometimes since I need to be super careful that my inertia doesn't make me fly off an edge after I land. Lastly, getting the dialog/cutscenes before each boss is a pain when you need to redo them multiple times.

112624879.review: Ahhh, Cave Story, a simultaneously comfy yet engaging masterpiece produced by Pixel. It captures the best parts of the classic Megaman games, such as the satisfy combat (but has a bunch more weapons, all which feel neccessary and fun to use) and linear but tightly constructed level design, whilst still maintaining a great sense of connectedness and adventure, which is why many compare to Metroid (whilst not being a metroidvania itself). Couple this with a greatly immersive narrative, with great and memorable characters and you've got yourself one of my favourite games ever made. Although I must say, Nicalis does not have the best record as a company, and unless you really love the new visuals or remastered soundtrack, I'd say the free version is plenty enough. Regardless this game is simply sublime in nearly every aspect, and is possibly one of the most innovative and important game of the 2000's, carving the way of indie gaming, and subsequently 90% of my steam library overall.

108545751.review:
A couple years ago, I made my own list of "top 10 best games released between 2010 and 2019."  Cave Story+ was #6.  Here was what I wrote to explain why:



Cave Story is another game I'd heard about for a long time before I played it, but I didn't know very much about it...other than one important thing.  With the boom in indie gaming in the 10s - and this isn't close to the last indie game on the list, so I certainly got in on that boom - people called Cave Story "the grandfather of indie gaming," a simple but great game made by one person.  I also heard its gameplay described as "sort of a mix of Metroid and Contra," and that sounded good to me, so at some point earlier in the decade I finally picked up Cave Story+ and went to find out why everyone was still talking about Cave Story, let alone why they were talking about how great it was.

It started out fun: Good platforming and shooting, catchy music, colorful and pretty graphics, and a lot of cute critters (plus one cute gynoid*).  Then, early on, I got stumped in one area and I was too stubborn (or stupid) to look up what I was supposed to do.  I abandoned it for years.

Then, feeling emboldened by overcoming another personal gaming challenge, I picked it up again and swallowed enough of my pride to look up a guide.  I'm glad I did because once I got past that part, everything good about the game kept getting better, and even when I failed, I was having a blast.  It says a lot about the quality of a game when, even if it's giving you a beating, you're still loving it.  Getting the best ending...that was an accomplishment.

I recommend this for anyone who wants to play a milestone in indie gaming and in gaming period.  But also, don't feel ashamed to look up a guide here and there; some of the things in this game are hard to find, especially when it comes to getting the best ending.

* That's as in, an android that appears female.  Yeah, they're called robots but even though you can tell they probably aren't human, they aren't all [u]that[/u] robotic.

108486456.review:
I want to preface this review by saying that Cave Story itself is an amazing game. It's an incredible one man passion project that is brimming with so attention love and care, from the beautiful pixel art graphics, the wonderful chiptune music, simple but challenging gameplay with a huge world to explore, and the amazing story with memorable characters. It's a freeware game that I would highly recommend everyone to experience. That said, I cannot recommend Cave Story+ on PC for the following reasons...

First and foremost, while this version has some new features over the original freeware version, those being updated graphics and new music, but what you're NOT getting with the PC version of Cave Story+ that the later produced Switch port received are a wealth of new content such as new challenge modes, Easy and Hard difficulty options, local co-op multiplayer, further visual improvements (e.g. animated dialogue portraits, new dynamic lighting effects), extra soundtrack options, and native widescreen presentation. So what PC players are getting with this version instead is essentially the same outdated re-release that used to available on the Wii Shop Channel from 2010.

106436331.review:
Having failed to enjoy this game recently and finding most bad reviews are about the publisher, not the game itself, I felt the need to add my voice to things. This is not a good game, and the drawbacks are present so early I don't fully understand how it became such a beloved classic except that it is/was free.

Firstly, little in this game feels rewarding. The concept of gaining little exp triangles to level up your guns like a shoot-'em-up is kind of interesting, as is losing said exp. on taking damage. However, with your minuscule health bar and the amount of damage enemies do, you're more likely to die and restart with full exp than have to scramble to make up the loss. Enemies are dropping SCADS of these little things, so it's trivial to go to max level with your weapons a quarter of the way into your travels to the next destination. Very early on you get an alternate weapon; a missile. It has limited ammo instead of a level system and feels like a slower, less-accurate version of the max level pistol. Why would I bother using this weapon? It doesn't seem to be better at killing certain enemies. I could conceive of losing all my gun levels and switching to the missile temporarily to farm exp, but I never actually lose my gun levels so what's the point?

Secondly, the "difficulty" is largely overinflated by the drunken camera sway. It's like calling Super Mario a precision platformer because you only play it while your friend is sitting next to you shaking your entire body. In more tense portions I would lose projectile-shooting enemies off-screen because what should be my typical screen real estate had suddenly shifted wobbily off-center. I would not mind the many enemies that can one-hit kill me if the screen would stay focused on my character.

The third and fourth issues are smaller gripes, but it's annoying to have to talk to every rabbit in rabbitville multiple times until I find the right rabbit to tell me I'm allowed to advance the plot when the game already bothered to give me the tools to intuit what to do next. I also had a harder time than expected discerning background objects from foreground platforms. At a glance I would not think this to be a problem, because the background objects are usually darker. I think perhaps there were some darker patches of earth that were foreground platforms in the rabbit village that messed with my ability to discern, but to find out for sure I'd have to turn the game back on and that's not happening.

This game had been described to me as Mega Man meets Kirby's Great Cave Offensive, and it is violently neither of those things. The graphics are cute, the music is fantastic, and I'm sure the story gets interesting eventually, but I had this game in my library for almost a decade before trying it, and I'm still mad at past me for spending 7.50 to buy it on sale.

104423994.review:
This is one of my most favorite games of all time, it has a well-written and engaging story, amazing soundtrack, good controls, and great art. The best ending route is not easy to get and quite challenging, but it's not impossible.

I have been familiar with this game for years now, but the only reason I'm writing a review *now* is that I noticed way too many people spreading misinformation about Nicalis, the publisher of Cave Story+, and suggest things like pirating the game or getting the freeware version instead, to "support" Pixel, the original developer of the game.

I hope these people will eventually realize that they are so wrong about so many things. I do agree that Nicalis has done (and is doing) scummy and questionable things, but claiming that they "scammed Pixel out of his money" or "scammed him into giving away all rights to the game" is just so dumb.

I want to make it very clear that Pixel DOES still earn from every single copy of this game. Every single time you purchase this game on Steam, Pixel gets revenue from it. And for those who doubt it, here's a tweet from Pixel himself, claiming that he still earns from Nicalis sales: https://twitter.com/oxizn/status/394822911824896000 (the tweet he replied to is gone now, so you'll have to take my word for it).

So no, don't pirate the game. If you do that, *you* are the one who is scamming Pixel. Sure, you support Nicalis by throwing money at them, but you also support Pixel for this beautiful game that he's created. Is that not what you want? To show gratitude to him for this game by supporting him *because* of the game?

102109018.review:
Pretty good game. Likable characters, fun to control and play, the weapon variety is pretty nice (though by the end of the game you'll mostly only be using one or two of them) and there's plenty to collect. My biggest gripe is the rather questionable game design at certain points. Instant death spikes are used sparingly, though part of me wish they weren't used at all [spoiler] (with an exception at the Blood-Stained Sanctuary, since there they're essential for the platforming of the first part) [/spoiler]. I'm also a pretty big fan of the trading mechanic, with you being able to [spoiler] save the Polar Star instead of trading it right away for the Machine Gun in favor of the stronger Snake or Spur. [/spoiler] The final dungeon of the game, [spoiler] the Blood-Stained Sanctuary [/spoiler], is only available if you're aiming for the Best Ending and is also a pretty big difficulty spike. Took me about 2 hours straight of blindly playing through it to beat it, including the final boss. It was, however, very satisfying to finally beat.

Overall, I'd probably give the game a solid 9/10. Generally speaking it's a very well made and charming game that set the scene for indies and will forever be in the "Mt. Rushmore" of indie games, together with Yume Nikki and the like. Its main problems stem from certain questionable game design decisions, but those are few and far between. Also, don't try the Best Ending if you're not that comfortable with the game's controls; it's gonna kick your ass. I know it sure kicked mine.

101721030.review:
This game is iconic as an early indie Metroidvania title. It's historical significance can't be denied. The conceptual design of the game is great, but I didn't find myself getting swept away in the game the way that I have by some other titles in the genre, both new and old. I can't really put my finger on why this is. I don't necessarily mind the old style graphics and music. I found the movement to be a bit awkward, although I would say the same about many older console games that I grew up on. So I can't fully explain it.

Those interested in replay-ability and challenge have plenty to like. The "best" ending is a grueling challenge. I wish there was a way to pursue both the "best" and "good" endings on a single run - without spoiling anything, I got to a place where I saved and didn't realize there was no turning back until it was too late. Since I wasn't enraptured by the game, I don't have the motivation to replay it to get the different achievements, endings, weapons, etc.

That said, I would recommend the game. It is satisfying, challenging, and well-designed, and I'm sure it would resonate with some people more than it did with me.

101353382.review: Cave Story is a game where you literally fall into a cave, with no idea of where you are or even who you are, steal a gun, and run. You meet the Mimiga, one of the races in this subterranean world, and protect them from the sinister machinations of The Doctor (not the one from the British time travel show), and get as many weapons as you can remember to use. Along the way, you can do everything from harvest jellyfish juice, find a bunch of dogs, and even talk to (and fight) a sentient mushroom. No other game I know of can make those promises. The game has three endings and piles of secrets that keep you coming back for more. But that's just regular Cave Story. Cave Story+ adds new graphics (if you like that sort of thing), access to the new and remastered soundtracks, and a bunch of special challenges to put your skills to the test. With all that said, this is a game that I first played years ago, recently played, and I'm sure will keep playing as soon as I finish this review. The only discrepancy in this version of the game is the ending (there seems to be no way to get past the credits), but I'm sure they've fixed that now. The game is a classic and will always be a classic. Good luck, and watch out for the bats...

99810879.review:
Cave Story is an indie classic that still lives up to today’s standards almost two decades later. The plus version adds onto and improves upon Pixel’s original view in a way that players both new and old can enjoy.

First, let’s talk about the soundtrack. Cave Story has a phenomenal soundtrack with a track for every situation. A calm theme for a hub area? Mimiga Village has it. An intense boss battle theme? Look no further than Eyes of Flame.

The option for remastered or classic style in terms of both graphics and soundtrack is excellent; and the fact that they are separate is even better! Wanna play with new visuals but the classic retro OST? You can do that.

As for the remastered graphics, they provide a fresh new look for the game while still keeping to the original’s charm. Also as stated previously, you can switch back to the old visuals if desired.

Overall, Cave Story+ is a great take on a classic platformer that is still going strong and hopefully does for years to come.

99201613.review:
Cave Story foi o primeiro indie que joguei. O Game original saiu lá para o final do ano de 2004, era o lendário game feito por um cara só. Daisuke "Pixel" Amaya fez a história, a engine, a música, a arte e tudo do game sozinho e do zero e disponibilizou gratuitamente em seu site. Essa atitude de Pixel mostrou que qualquer um com visão, foco e amor pode rivalizar até grandes empresas de jogos. Cave Story pode até ser chamado de o primeiro Indie já que o game influenciou e deu um empurrão e apoio moral para quem queria começar a desenvolver jogos e as empresas viram o potencial em entusiastas e hobbistas tentarem fazer um jogo  tanto é, que hoje em dia as ferramentas para fazer um jogo são gratuitas até que o jogo fique relativamente famoso. 
Cave Story+ é um remaster com gráficos, musica melhorados mas a história e jogabilidade do game estão ambos sem quaisquer alterações. O game é um metroidvania,retro, 2D, shooter,plataforming. O criador do game disse que tirou influência justamente dos jogos que ele jogava em sua infância que seriam metroid, castlevania e mario.
Quote é o personagem principal e acordado sem lembrar de nada e (Isso muda quando você pega um certo item no game e você pode jogar com outro personagem) controlado por você, Quote irá explorar as cavernas a procura de itens e progredir na história e se envolver com os seres chamados Mimigas e tentar entender o que está acontecendo. O game também conta com um arsenal de armas, upgrades de life e sistema experiência onde cada arma tem ate um nivel 3 de poder alterando bastante a forma como ela funciona. 
Cave Story, como a maioria dos games japoneses, possui vários fins  e cada um tem de ser feito algo bem especifico para poder acessá-lo então não tenha vergonha de usar um Guia caso queira.
Recomendadissimo é o game que faz parte dos tesouros dos games e é uma das conquistas que foram adquiridas com a maturidade do entretenimento audio visual durante esses anos.

98860504.review:
Cave Story, even Cave Story+ is an old game. Much of it might be seen as outdated by today's standards. It has little puzzle solving and a few interesting combat mechanics and platforming speedrunners might focus on. And quite a few guide-dang-it moments if you're trying to accomplish a particular goal on a given playthrough.

None of these reasons are the reason you might fall in love with Cave Story. And I can't really tell you any details about why you'd fall in love with Cave Story. It is a game with a world that feels truly alive and deep, at least to me. It is imaginative, and while it has few really fleshed out characters, they're all fairly well written.

It is important to note that other than some extras and improved graphics, Cave Story+ doesn't offer all that much more than the default Cave Story, which is free. So if you're still on the fence, and you're not sure if you'd like this game, I invite you to Google it, and try out the free version. If, by the end of the Egg Chamber, you're certain that you don't really like it, then ah well. But if you do like the original game, you'll probably like Cave Story+. Even though I'm not much of a snob about graphics, the more well defined graphics give it an extra bit of depth.

97868449.review:
[b]NOTE: I CANNOT RECOMMEND GETTING ANY OF THE REMASTERS ANYMORE INCLUDING THIS ONE, PIXEL HAS PRACTICALLY BEEN SCAMMED BY NICALIS, GO TO THE FAN SITE AND DOWNLOAD THE ORIGINAL CAVE STORY FOR FREE OR PIRATE THE REMASTER, IF YOU WANT MONEY TO GO TO THE ACTUAL DEV BUY KERO BLASTER.[/b]

Alright, with that out of the way, Here's the review.

Cave story is really special to me, aside from it basically being the grandfather of indie games as we know them, it also was a huge part of my childhood via the Dsiware and homebrew PSP ports, as i owned them during a rough time of my life.

Cave story is a retro themed Metroidvania created by one man in his spare time; Pixel, or by his real name Daisuke Amaya. It was then released free of charge online in Japanese. eventually English speaking audiences noticed how well designed cave story was, considering everything from the engine, sound, story and graphics were made by one person, this eventually resulted in a relatively well known fan translation group that often translates Japanese-only titles Aeon Genesis to fully translate the game into English, which was followed by many translations for different languages, allowing everyone to experience the game fully. A tribute site was made for discussion and even modding and boom, instant cult classic and the stepping stone for good non triple A games was created.

Cave story plays out in a blend of metroidvania and run and gun type attributes, while exploring the mysterious island our mute protagonist has found himself in you'll find many secrets, such as new and unique weapons, capsules that increase your total health, upgrades to existing weapons, funny yet useless items and even 3 different endings. Your weapons (for the most part) are based off a level system, when you kill an enemy they may drop shards that when picked up; get enough of these and your weapon will level up, increasing it's damage and sometimes overall playstyle. Platforming is a secondary, as you may come across arrays of spikes or other hazards that must be outright avoided with you gaining a new form of mobility later on. The game definitely has a learning curve, and the final areas and bosses can be quite difficult, but the learning curve is relatively friendly.

Overall, with an endearing story, lovable characters, great gameplay and amazing music, i cannot recommend this game enough, but do pixel a favor and don't buy it. download the aeon genesis translation here: https://www.cavestory.org/download/cave-story.php

Just download the original Japanese freeware release. Literally the only change Nicalis made in this version that's worth ANYTHING is the ability to maximize the window.

The new music is bad.
The new translation is bad.
The Japanese text processing is broken.
The achievements are nonsense.
The new challenge maps are completely disconnected from the actual game in every way.
The seasonal reskins are pointless, because the game gives you no reason to come back over time and never receives updates of any kind.
The new difficulty levels are lazy and unbalanced; Easy mode literally just halves every damage number, and hard mode is absolutely nothing more than a forced 3 hearts challenge like the Zelda speedrunning community would come up with.

No meaningful new content was actually integrated into the game itself whatsoever in a way that allows you to engage with it on your own terms, with your own equipment, with checkpoints and pacing.
And the majority of the disjointed challenge maps/modes were fan-created to begin with, from a community that was immediately gagged with anti-modding pressure on the site admin afterwards that eventually forced him to retire.

I bought this on Humble Bundle for a dollar, and explicitly specified that the dollar goes to charity.

95817790.review:
By sheer obligation on account of the amount of time I spent playing this, I ought to admit that I got something out of it. Enough to keep me hooked to play toward a mediocre ending. However, I cannot in my heart recommend it.

Let me start with the positives. The world is open and scattered aspects of it seem to build a likable and distinctive world. A race of cute bunny people, some names and a little bit of history, outsiders staying on, some drama and conflict with valid concerns on part of a grumpy rabbit, and why lie: Some of the female characters shown are, as far as simplified pixel-women go, fairly attractive. Can't deny I had a thing for Misty, Curly Brace, and the transmogrified rabbit-human-girl.

Gameplay, I remember, is navigable, and can be occasionally outright fun. That being said, other times I remember it can be quite awkward. Often enough, I say, that it can make clearing some sections that should feel epic more like a chore. If 2D shooter combat is what you're after, I recommend looking elsewhere, such as at Ian Campbell's Bleed games, or at the Cally's Caves franchise.

The biggest appeal for gameplay in my opinion is the exploration and the progression. Getting a new weapon is satisfying, as is testing it out. Moreover, when you finally find doors, gates, objects, and characters of interest in the world, it can feel satisfying. Each of those, though, are relatively sparsely populated; the middling combat experience is more common and stands between each.

--

The Story is arguably the biggest deal-breaker for me. It starts out interesting, and increasingly so. Characters and rules of the world are introduced that seem like they could be important, and create a web of intrigue that could truly feel rich and deep.

That is not the case. Many characters and rules I met that are interesting and set a potent first impression, enough to commit them to memory for later in the experience, play a role only once or twice later in the game and then they just disappear or outright die off. Like a kid at his very first story-circle experience in the school's creative writing club, shooting off items back to back while it's still his turn, Cave Story's, well, story, is just a bunch of factors tacked on of which almost none- I honestly want to say, none outright- of the characters or places we meet actually get fleshed out enough to matter. 

--

This makes two general elements of Cave Story that would be good, not so much:

=I have heard that Cave Story has more than one ending. Well, for me, multiple endings only matter if the story elements and the world itself are memorable, likable, and interconnected; the multiple endings can give a chance to learn how different choices can affect the same characters we care about differently.

With too little to go on to care about these characters, and with the story being all over the place, this would-be boon that could bring me back is downgraded to a neutral.

-Cave Story's story, dialogue, sequence of events, world, and imagery are very dark. I would like very strongly to consider this to be a positive. Sincerely dark stories with cartoonish imagery and non-human characters, frankly, are extremely rare. Especially in games. I've wanted to find one for quite a while.

However, with the characters being fleeting after their first impressions, the darkness of Cave Story is just unsettling. It seems like the writers are just out to freak the audience out as much as possible by throwing whatever creepy or tragic thing they can at you, and there's an uncanny valley disparity between how much the characters are supposed to matter and how much they actually do- and in turn how much it matters that these dark things happen to them. In fact like the character themselves, the dark stuff just gets piled on one after the other without any apparent structure or reverence.

--

Clearly there's an audience out there that is keen on Cave Story. Enough for it to have the following it does. However, I for one cannot mentally put myself in their shoes. Cave Story offers a good promise, but it falls short on too much. I must recommend against it. I am glad to finally close this chapter and leave it behind.

I do recommend this game, but I will say I was kinda disappointed because I thought this was gonna be a longer metroidvania, something along the lines of Hollow Knight.

I'm kinda torn on the weapon EXP system. On one hand, some upgrades are pretty good. On the other... well, most weapons aren't actually that good and losing levels is super frustrating (specially the sword, since you lose max level if you take a single hit)

The areas are kinda hit or miss. Some are quite entertaining (IMO the Sand Zone was the best) while others are either bland or really frustrating.

While the bosses do have a smooth difficulty curve I've never been a fan of them being balanced around spawning minions that you can kill for resources, a type of boss of which this game has plenty of, specially in its later stages. The final boss can also be quite frustrating since dying in that battle means you have to rebattle 3 bosses before you get to them again.

Overall, it is a game that progresses the way you'd imagine a very short metroidvania would, but some of its mechanics haven't aged well for me.

93481953.review:
Cave Story+ es un juego estilo metroidvania, muy entretenido que gustará a los amantes del género.
Gráficamente presenta una estética manga que, sin ser brillante, raya un buen nivel. Los personajes que se nos presentan a lo largo de la historia tienen su carisma y han sido creados con detalle.
Su música está lograda, pegadiza incluso, y por momentos varía según el momento de la historia y la tensión que se respire. Los efectos de sonido cumplen sin más.
La jugabilidad es buena, con movimientos precisos del personaje y una curva ascendente de dificultad que, en ocasiones, sube hasta niveles desesperantes (sobre todo al enfrentarnos con algunos jefes finales).
Cabe destacar que la historia que se nos va contando está bien trabajada y que la posibilidad de descubrir varios finales diferentes hace que el juego se haga bastante rejugable. Además, si quieres conseguir todos los logros, deberás pasarte el juego en tres niveles de dificultad distintos y superar unos retos (desbloqueados durante tu aventura) que requerirá de un gran nivel por parte del jugador debido a su alta dificultad.
En definitiva, es un juego con una duración excelente, y que muestra un nivel bastante alto en todos sus apartados, pero que no destaca en ninguno de sus aspectos ni a nivel técnico ni de originalidad. Es un buen título, recomendado, pero no llega al nivel de los mejores del género.

NOTA: 7,5/10

92428801.review:
[h1]Otherworldly[/h1]
I've heard many mentions of Cave Story in the game community but never got around to check it out until after I finished Kero Blaster, made by the same developer: Studio Pixel. What started out as a Flash-based, platformer shooter, got eventually remastered for release on PC and other platforms.

You play as a soldier robot, Quote, who wakes up without memories in an underground world inhabited by dangerous and cute creatures (even both). You'll also find Mimiga, the sentient species who play the major role in your story progress. Pieces of the story background will fall into place as you find new locations and characters, which have lead into this current state of environment the game is based on. The characters - good and bad - are quite memorable, in spite of my subdued awareness of what's going on in the first place but it got easier to grasp when I came back and started over to finish Cave Story. There are multiple endings to it and then there's the true ending that is even more satisfying but oh, so extreme to enable. If you're like me, you'd stick to a walkthrough guide strictly to not miss any minor criterias necessary and even then, you'll have a long final stage to clear your way on while staying alive. I'm sure the satisfaction level there is on par with Dark Souls but personally, I called quits and resorted to watching a playthrough on Youtube instead. For shame, oh me... ^_^

The action gameplay gets slippery at times, as my character maneuvres a little faster than necessary for platforming scenes but it's bearable enough for me to reach the standard ending. The choices you make affect what arsenal you'll have along the way but all in all, most of them are quite practical for ground and mid-air combat, situationally.

The remastered version not only improves the visuals but also presents overhauled soundtrack, which in itself is mostly catchy and memorable. You're also free to switch to older versions of the soundtrack for some lo-fi experience but the new ones are relatively meaty and livelier.

I can understand why Cave Story is a cult classic of its time, considering its fragmented yet cohesive story, adorable cast and a varied world to explore. If you can bear the twitchy nature of platforming, saving habits, optionally even dare undertake the punishing means for the true ending, Cave Story+ is worth playing through.

Personal favorite soundtrack: Meltdown.

I remember first finding this game all the way back on the Nintendo DSi Shop when I was 11 or 12. This game was one of a lot of firsts for me. It was the first indie game I ever played, the first non-Mario 2D platformer, and it was the first game I fell in love with because of the story. Since then, I have purchased this game on pretty much every Nintendo console up to the Switch, and now I have it on Steam.

While the movement isn't as fluid as other 2D platformers I've played, the game still has fun platforming and every weapon is really fun to use. However at one point in the game, you obtain an item that significantly improves your movement in the air, and it is brilliant. Almost every enemy and boss is fun to fight and there's a lot of replayability in restricting your weapon selection during battles. The extra challenge modes are also really nice additions. This game gives me a lot of nostalgia, and even though I can beat it in under 5 hours with my experience, it was still fun going through this game again.

This one is a Megman Style game with a classic style. Highly suggested. If you got a few hours to kill this game is worth playing! Just take it slow at the start, It rewards precision play at the beginning. Don't expect a Run and Gun!

It also has RPG elements. Killing a monster/baddie will drop Doritos ((orange triangles)). These power up your existing weapons. The game also has branching storylines (4 or 5). and Special weapons you can only gain once in a playthrough (Be careful who you hand/trade things to!)

It's definitely not the worst game in the world, but it shows its age (and development limitations), and would be a good buy at $5, but definitely not $15. Poor balance, bad save system. That said, maybe I would have had a better time if I had looked things up beforehand, but that shouldn't be necessary. Considering I have a good deal of experience with old school platformers like this (it plays very similarly to Flash platformers, tbqh), I can't imagine how bad a time one would have as a casual player.
Don't be afraid to use easy mode, although I have no idea what changes in it since it isn't transparent about what the difficulty affects.
If the game were priced at $5, I wouldn't be complaining at all, and at $10, it might still be worth a buy with a fair bit of prior knowledge. At $15, it's really only worth it to someone who is thrilled by old game design, and isn't bothered at all by such irritating game design decisions as putting you up against 4 bosses in a row with no heals or saves inbetween. If you fit that description, more power to you! I would absolutely recommend this game to you. For the rest, not so much.

And before you comment, remember that whether a game is worth purchasing is determined by the enjoyment one gets from it. Some will be more bothered by poor and/or unfair game design, some less so. This isn't about gitting gud, this is about specific people having fun, or the lack thereof.

88169352.review:
Cave Story is a masterpiece and probably one of the best platforming games of all time. It has incredible gameplay, great pixel art, legendary music and a great story with lots of lore.  This game can be acquired for free (legally), but its worth buying here for the HD graphics update, remastered soundtrack, new rush modes, difficulty settings and achievements. 

Cave Story feels great to play and the game does a good job at pushing players to slowly mastering the game. The gameplay is based around using a jet pack that lets the player move in any direction and make complicated maneuvers with a limited energy bar. The game has ten different kinds of guns that encourage different styles of fighting that are all viable. All the guns can be upgraded and are all worth using. The game is pretty complicated and becomes really challenging, but this happens over the course of the game so its not overwhelming. Cave Story game only demands some level of mastery near the end of a playthrough, and only demands mastery for the true ending (which should be done on a second playthrough).  This version of the game adds an easy setting, but even that difficulty is challenging as it just means a few extra hearts. 

Cave story has great pixel art for both its gameplay and cutscenes. The in-game art is very functional as its easy to tell what is happening on screen despite there being tons of enemies and bullets on the screen. The story plays out in-game with text, but it does the job of showing what is happening while allowing the imagination to fill in the details.  The character portraits for even minor characters are great and the few cutscenes in the game are very memorable. 

The Cave Story soundtrack is legendary. The game has a diverse soundtrack of 8-bit music that reflects the moods of places in the game and moments in the story very well. The soundtrack holds up on its own as music and songs do not get old even on stages that demand lots of repeats. 

The story of Cave Story has multiple endings that justify multiple playthroughs, but the way these endings are handled is very strange. It would better to not spoil the story, but it is one of heroes, corrupting evil and sacrifice. Its very memorable and there is a lot of lore to uncover so its worth paying attention to. The way the multiple endings are handled is very strange, and a guide is required to get them. The way that the true ending is reached is very arbitrary and convoluted. There are multiple triggers for alternative endings that can be easily missed, but for a first playthrough the game can be played blind just fine. 

Cave Story is a masterpiece, and its amazing that the game was made by a single developer in their spare time. This version of the game in particular is very much worth getting.

87172381.review:
Cave Story has such an interesting story. It was created in 2004, after 5 years in continuous development, and it was released for free. That's right, there's a freeware version online. After the gigantic interest from the media and the great reviews, which claimed it even rivaled paid games such as GBA games Metroid and Castlevania, it was ported for free to Xbox, and in 2011 Cave Story+ arrived in Steam; re-translated, with a revamped soundtrack, improved graphics, and extra modes, making it a commercial success on PC. It was also released on the Nintendo shop.

The age doesn't matter, it still is an amazing metroidvania experience, with one of the best soundtracks created. There are some interesting mechanics that haven't been picked up in other games. For example, the leveling system of the weapons; Basically, you have 4 levels per weapon. You receive exp by killing enemies with them, and that improves the weapon. And here's the catch: if you get hit, you'll lose exp. This makes for an interesting mechanic, forcing the players to try their best to not get hurt, not only because of the HP, but also for the experience points, handicapping you even further.

The game is not extremely long, you can beat it in 12-18 hours, and there aren't boring sequences. The story goes straight ahead, revealing itself step by step, without the cutscenes/texts being tiring or time consuming.

I recommend it completely to any fan of the genre, and if you're feeling extra cheap, get the freeware version. I'm pretty sure most of you will decide to support Pixel after beating his game.

Well this is a great game and I am glad I played it there is no way in hell I actually recommend you play it.

Before I get to why let me go over some positives. The game looks decent, its done its best to match the 2004 pixel art version with updated looks that don't lose the charm of the original. The game play is pretty tight with a good amount of control that I did feel like it was my fault if I messed up... To an extent, but I'll get into that in a sec. And the story and characters are well done enough that I did want to keep going to see more of them and what would happen. HOWEVER

FUCKKKKKKK The difficulty spikes in this game! Oh holy shit! I cannot tell you just how awful going for the true ending is. I do want to complain a bit about that but the game makes you go out of your way to go after it (and I only knew about it from word of mouth so I only have myself to blame) like not going to help someone after they look to fall to their near death, which you could only possibly know on a second play through. But if you do know about it and try to go for it... First of all have a walk through open because there is shit that you will need to know ahead of time or you'll miss it. Secondly Good Fucking Luck. Because I consider myself decent at platformers but the last cave (hidden) was nearly a 3 hour affair for me. And then I got to the last area, the blood stained sanctuary and imagine the hardest bullet hell platformer you've ever seen. And stretch that to 9 minutes with 4 bosses in it. AND NO SAVE POINTS! No thanks. I'm not dedicating 12 hours of my life to that.
But my real complaint about Cave Story 17 years later is that there just isn't enough checkpoints. The game is already frustratingly difficult without having to backtrack miles to get to where you just were. The final boss coming to mind which has a 4 part gauntlet with very little health drops during. But on the other hand if this game did get more liberal with the checkpoints the game would lose all its difficulty and you'd be done with it in about 4 hours. Which fair enough if you're looking for that level of challenge. I thought I was but ended up biting off more then I could really chew.
Cave Story is a very important game for the indi scene but at the same time I don't know that I could call it worth playing now. If you're into the history of gaming I do think its a notable game that you should try, but I don't think you should be required to finish it. Good game, but I won't be returning

85632570.review:
Cave Story + was the eighth game of my 2021 challenge to finish all the uncompleted games in my Steam library in alphabetical order and write a review of them once complete! My challenge for this game was to finish the main story [spoiler]though I didn't do the hell level, I'll come back for that another day![/spoiler] - Cave Story + took me 13 hours in total to complete.

If you like old-school platformers with a decent but not impossible level of challenge and haven't played this one yet I'd recommend it. The game is one of the old classics, with metroidvania elements, a good selection of weapons and enemies and some challenging bosses. It's not easy - I'd rate it up slightly easier than the original megaman games, but it's one where a little persistence pays off. Very enjoyable and I'm glad I pushed my way past the many, many deaths this one doled out to me!
