83699850.review:
Cave Story is a brisk and subtle indie masterpiece!

This game is so effortlessly engaging. All its primary elements feel well considered and benefit the game in some way. From the weapons and upgrades, to the level and character designs, its all really top notch stuff. The feeling of progression in Cave Story, weather it be gameplay or story related, is just so captivating. Its the perfect blend of platforming, shooting, and exploration. As soon as I finished the game I immediately began another playthrough. 
This version also offers a plethora of options available for graphical styles, soundtrack versions, and even holiday aesthetics. 

The biggest issue I have with Cave Story is the save point locations. A few segments got repetitive because of odd placements. The sand zone also drags just ever so slightly because of the dog collecting thing, but eh, its really not a big deal. 

I totally recommend Cave Story! 
Know that you can also always play the original 2004 version, which is freeware.

83677185.review: It is a very fun little indie game

83630296.review: Cave Story is a wonderful indie darling that has a rather obtuse way to achieve it's endings. I don't mean for this to come out swinging negatively, but when I look back at the game, that's really my only problem with it. This would all be fine if the logic to getting the correct ending made some sense, but largely it doesn't. Still to say the game is ruined by such a process is taking things too far, and really not where Cave Story shines the most. Cave Story, for all purposes, is a wonderful platform shooter that incorporates exploration quite well to make for a fun and interesting experience. I wouldn't say it's on the level of Metroidvania's, but it does feel like an older game with how often it likes to steps up challenges, while still having a rather forgiving modern age curve. The story is passable with a rather interesting plot about slavery, robots, and magic, but when you start thinking about it harder it starts to really show it's holes. Overall, Cave Story feels like an old school adventure game while being more forgiving than one, and honestly that makes it such an enjoyable experience.

83601911.review: Cave Story is a classic for all the right reasons. This 2d metroidvania has terrific pixel art, challenging gameplay, and a pretty hefty quest to keep you engaged. The story, while not the game's strong point, does keep you engaged right up until the end. If you have any interest in 2d action adventure games, you should totally check this out.

Go find the free version of the game, and if you really want to spend money, then donate it to Studio Pixel, the original developer, instead. He did all of the work while this company is cashing in on it.

80541491.review:
[i]Cave Story[/i] is a wonderful game, it's easily one of the greatest games ever made and among some of my my all-time favorite video games. Without spoiling anything, [i]Cave Story[/i] is a one-man passion project by Daisuke "Pixel" Amaya that pays homage to classic video games with beautiful pixel art graphics, amazing music, a great story, memorable characters, and gameplay that builds up to a fun and challenging [i]Metroid[/i]-styled experience. [i]Cave Story[/i] is a lovingly crafted game that I recommend everyone to play. So why am I giving this game a negative review then?

NiCALiS, the publisher and current prison warden of the [i]Cave Story[/i] IP, has been not only ripping off Daisuke's work (among other smaller developers) and not paying him for the [i]Cave Story+[/i] re-releases on Wii Ware and onward, they've also abandoned the PC version of this supposed "updated" version of Cave Story for years and treating PC players like second-class citizens by not giving them updates from the later Switch port, which has much more features, new bonus content, new lighting effects, 16:9 presentation, local co-op support, and even more soundtrack options than this obsolete port has. Rather than do the right thing for PC players and port the newer version back to PC and fix the issues it has that they neglected to fix for all this time, they decided to cuck them over with the newer Switch port and also taken down a few fan-made ports that tried to improve this version of [i]Cave Story+[/i] with DMCA takedowns because god-forbid fans try to fix this crap.

Please heed my advice and DO NOT buy this game (or [i]any[/i] game with NiCALiS's name on it) if you care about supporting smaller independent developers like Daisuke and instead use that money to buy his other game, Kero Blaster, and play the freeware release of [i]Cave Story[/i]. Don't even bother buying this game on Epic Games Store or [noparse]GOG.com[/noparse] either since NiCALiS is also selling the same outdated PC version of [i]Cave Story+[/i] with the only difference being that it's DRM-free unlike the Steam version, but then again, so is the original freeware version, so why even throw your money away for an inferior version [i]Cave Story[/i] with a worse localization?

80455740.review:
Cave Story+ is an excellent game that you shouldn't buy. Play this game if you can, it's wonderful, just don't buy it. Cave Story was originally published for free online, and hopefully it's still available as such, either in its original form or in fan remakes. Note the phrasing "hopefully". We'll get to that later. For now, I'll just proceed like this is a normal review.

Cave Story is a true indie game in the spirit that game like Super Meat Boy, Spelunky, and even small-studio games like Supergiant's Hades are carrying on, made by a single talented (and somewhat reclusive) japanese dev known online as 'Pixel'.

Gameplay-wise, Cave Story is a light metroidvania with a heavy emphasis on shooting, with a variety of weapons available to choose from, although not all of them are available in every run. The game's relatively unique weapon experience system rewards with experience shards for killing enemies, which upgrade your individual weapon if you collect enough to fill up its experience bar, but you lose that experience if you take damage, rewarding high-performance gameplay simply and effectively. Most weapons have three levels of experience, and will gain additional effects as they increase in level, like firing several more projectiles, or firing in a different pattern. 

The game is also pretty short (beatable in around two hours for a player who's reasonably familiar with it), highly replayable (there are a few choices early on in the game that have effects later on, changing which weapons you get at certain points or determining your elegibility for the best ending), and can be extremely difficult near the end, especially on the route to the best ending. It's a great way to burn a few hours on a fun, but fairly simple game experience, it's a reasonable challenge for players interested in being challenged, it's a good game all around, just... *don't buy it.*

So, that all sounds great, right? Cave Story + is a wonderful game, so why shouldn't you buy it?
Nicalis, the publisher, are awful people.
Pixel originally published Cave Story for free online, similarly to other cult-classic japanese indie titles like Yume Nikki, and Cave Story + is an enhanced remake created for sale, which is now published by Nicalis. Reportedly, under the contract Pixel signed with Nicalis, they get 0% of the money from Nicalis's sales of Cave Story +, because Pixel was lied to about the contents of the contract.
Furthermore, Nicalis are now undergoing an aggressive DMCA-takedown campaign against every freeware version of Cave Story they can find online, whether it uses the source code they actually own or not, which is in direct conflict with the spirit in which Pixel originally developed the game.
That's just the tip of the iceberg too. There are all sorts of reports about Nicalis management being horrible human beings and not just a predatory publisher, and furthermore reports of them mistreating other indie devs they've published for.

So, in summary: Cave Story + is a wonderful game, but Nicalis don't deserve your money. Go out and find a free version of Cave Story online while you still can.

78311606.review:
I have no familiarity with the publisher Nicalis.  I can confirm that [url=https://www.cavestory.org/download/cave-story.php]the original freeware game[/url] is great and the additions from this remake are worthless, including under baked difficulty modes.  My recommendation is based purely on the strength of that original game as this remake does not tarnish it.

Cave Story is an odd floaty-platformer run-and-gun that gradually evolves into an amazing series of boss rushes.  Unlike many free-running games with backtracking, enemies remain relevant because receiving damage also downgrades your weaponry.  There are a few too many weapons to discover which makes swapping between them mid-boss infeasible, but the ability to exchange your starting weapon for one of multiple weapons throughout the game is neat and affords fair replayability.

In a peculiar design decision, an optional late-game upgrade fundamentally changes movement mechanisms which unlocks a series of end-game challenges that are awesome to behold.

Its story delivers, by the bye.  It manages to hit a variety of emotional beats, particularly impressive how it does so through the pacing and design of its stages.

77858770.review:
I checked this game out a while back because I had heard it was, like, [b]the[/b] first indie game. After having dropped a good amount of time into it, I can see why it pioneered the indie space in the way it did.

The gameplay has tight controls, though the player feels like it has a lot of weight to it (I got used to it pretty quick). The story was a lot more compelling than I expected it to be and took a lot of interesting turns; it didn't feel like it fell into many tropey narratives. The lore is also pretty deep and there's a lot of backstory to just about everything you come across, and for the most part you actually have to go digging for it which I really like.

There is a good deal of replay value based on certain decisions you make over the course of any playthrough, which can affect what items you can obtain and a couple of mutually-exclusive outcomes and endings.

The secret challenge area at the end of the game is incredibly difficult and I have not completed it as of yet. It pushes the game's mechanics and level design as well as your abilities to their limits in such a brutal way; expect to die a lot in the process of working your way deeper each time.

There are a couple of areas I thought could have been done better (there are a couple of [i]very[/i] specific things you need to do to save certain characters that were not outlined anywhere I could find except online in guides or wikis), but given that this was basically the first game of its type I can hardly fault it. In some ways it's a throwback to classic games from the 80's and 90's that explained little and forced people to collaborate with each other to figure it out. I have mixed feelings on this method of design but it does get people talking and brainstorming, which I love the detective aspect of.

Overall, I really enjoy Cave Story and all it has to offer. I definitely think it will be regarded as one of the classics of its time.

The controls are good, responsive, and not at all complicated, with dynamic and intense gameplay you explore scenarios in the best Metroidvania style, with many challenges that always require attention and can catch the less experienced players off guard. 74145313.review:
Wow, what a trip this game was. I adored every second I played of it, from start to finish. Thank you Studio Pixel and Nicalis for giving us this experience of a life time. While it was short, it was simple and sweet, too, and there's a ton of replayability this game will present to you.

You play as Quote, an amnesiac robot soldier sent in from the surface to the underground caverns of a floating island who is mistakenly believed to be on a mission to slaughter all the Mimiga, the species of rabbit-dog like creatures who are forced to carry out orders under the control of the Doctor, who is using the power of the Demon Crown to his own will. He's planning to feed the Mimiga red flowers so they can transform into monstrous creatures so the Doctor can lead an army of them on the surface to take over it. But worry not, you will meet characters along the way who will aid you in your perilous journey to interfere with the Doctor's nefarious plans and to save the Mimiga and the rest of the world. Such characters include: 
• Curly Brace; another amnesiac robot soldier who is very emotional and shows a soft spot for the Mimiga
• Sue Sakamoto; a human turned into a Mimiga who is hiding from the Doctor's capture
• Kazuma Sakamoto; Sue's brother, who was one of the scientists who arrived on the island along with his family and the Doctor
• Momorin Sakamoto; Sue and Kazuma's mother, who was an aid to the Doctor before he betrayed her
• Professor Booster; another one of the research team's scientists who specializes in rocket jetpacks
and more!

You'll also meet many enemies and bosses who will stand in your way, such as Misery, a haughty and arrogant servant to the Doctor who possesses witch powers, Balrog, who works alongside Misery to crush any soldier who gets in the Crown Holder's way, and Ballos, who, without spoiling, will ultimately become one of the biggest threats in the game.

And now for the pros and cons for this game - 

Pros: 
• Allows switching between original and remastered graphics, as well as old and new music
• As noted above, the game contains many memorable characters who will work with or defy you, and none feel cheesy or poorly written
• The game can be really humorous at times, while serious at other points, providing a balance that makes for a grabbing and attentive experience
• Loads of weapon choices and upgrades, including your trusty and reliable Polar Star, the Machine Gun that allows you to hover in mid-air by firing, and the Missile Launcher that blast foes and deals tons of damage. You can also trade your weapon in (the Polar Star) to get other powerful choices as well!
• Soundtrack is one of the best things you'll ever hear in a video game, from emotional pieces to uplifting songs that will send you blasting your way throughout the underground caverns
• Secrets and item upgrades await to make you an even more stronger soldier
• Challenging and hectic boss fights that will send you scrambling on the edge of your seat
• Additional bonuses, such as Curly Story, where you play from Curly's point of view, and several challenge modes
• Tons of achievements to collect for the nifty achievement hunter
• One of the neatest little aspects is if you alt-tab out of the game, the game's currently playing music will play in the background but in a lower volume

Cons:
• Enemies damage you frequently and can overwhelm you if you're not careful enough where you're stepping
• No proper fullscreen ratio, but the original ratio will add a classic flair to the game
• There are no objective reminders, so you really need to focus on NPC dialogue as well as look through computer terminals to know where you're going

A classic and one of the most iconic indie games of all time, Cave Story, or Doukutsu Monogatari, is simply one of the best games you can get on Steam. It was developed, composed, and drawn by a lone developer, Pixel, and his work shines through, comparatively better than what other teams of developers can even put out today. It's also available for free at https://www.cavestory.org/ as a free download, so if you wish to support him there as well, I highly support that notion. Now, get on and save the fate of the Mimiga already, their lives as well as many others are depending on you!

Cave Story: my childhood game. The game that showed me just how compelling a video game's characters, gameplay, and plot could be. Cave Story has stayed my favorite game since I was 7 years old when I played the demo on the good ol' Wii Shop.

Unlike some games, this game grows with you. It manages to always be engaging and so much fun because you arent bored that its too easy but you certainly embrace the challenge- especially those who dare to seek the True Ending.

Everything you do feels satisfying: exploring and finding a secret weapon, boss fights, backtracking- oh, did I mention the music? I'd love to explain how the music is the best in its genre but you'll have to play to know ;) (or youtube it ya lazy butt :p)
Either way, words still fail me to this day how such a masterful game could exist. Don't got $15? Go to the official tribute site and play it for FREE!!! That'd right, the original was a passion project which Pixel, the developer, made the programs to make the music and sprites from scratch and then used those programs to make the game AND release it for free.
This game deserves all your love, whether you want to experience the hella nice 16-bit sprites or dont got any money, its there for everyone to enjoy.

Great lil' game! Nicalis can absolutely go choke on a bag of dicks but otherwise, Studio Pixel (lad that actually did this!) is great. You can actually get the original **free** game from his website if you so wish! 

One of the very first indie games out there, cave story's a 2004 retro 8 bit platformer. It holds up. Quite well. The story's captivating, the gameplay's tight, the movement's alright, the jumps in specific are kinda floaty but you get used to it very quickly. It has some classic old game dev bullshit techniques where you can lock yourself out of something good, and there's stuff you most likely *need* a walkthrough to figure out your first time around but, yeah! It's fine 'cause it's not a huuuuuuuge game. It looks big your first time through but, once you play through it again you'll realize it's not the longest game! 72771447.review:
A short, simple burst of arcade excitement that's very easy to pick up and master.
Much like a cave itself, it only looks decent on the surface level, but once you delve a little further in, the controls, music,  story, enemies, etc. just skyrocket in quality and wonder.
Gameplay is rather straightforward, the mechanics of jumping, flying and shooting are a breeze to get the hang of, but as you continue playing you're given a variety of tools and weapons to tinker around with. [strike]even though the Spur does pretty much everything you'd want and more but disregard that[/strike]
Difficulty was meticulously pieced together, with some stronger enemy and boss AIs serving a real threat if the player is not prepared. Ballos and the Bloodstained Sanctuary spring to mind for an incredible spike in the game's difficulty, and the best part is that even though it's considered the hardest area in the entire game, it's not frustratingly impossible. The fluidity of the controls and the forgiving skill ceiling ensure most players will improve greatly in a short amount of time.
Progression moves along at such a brisk pace, introducing plenty of interesting characters, and yet you notice an extremely sudden, dark turn in the story's tone, which only encourages the player more to reach the Doctor and just kick his face in.
Cave Story was undoubtedly a fundamental inspiration for future indie retro-styled platformers and shooters, and is by all definitions a classic.

4/5 - It's like Mega Man but with Balfrog

72748233.review:
Este juego es asquerosamente malo. Hace tiempo que no tengo la urgencia de escribir un análisis sobre un producto que consumo, tal vez la última vez que tuve esta sensación con Steins;Gate, el cual sigue siendo el análisis más largo que he escrito hasta la fecha, exponiendo en no sé cuántos párrafos lo superlativamente mala que me pareció. No he tenido tanto asco por un videojuego desde hace mucho tiempo, cuya racha ha sido cortada por Cave Story.

Se me hace un poco difícil ordenar mis pensamientos, pero hablaré en primer lugar sobre su jugabilidad. El juego en sí es un indie shooter plataformero en el que tendremos que abrirnos camino a golpe de un arsenal de armas relativamente amplio acorde a su duración. La realidad es que, en mi caso, acabé usando sólo el lanzacohetes y la machine gun, y en ocasiones contadas la bola de fuego, por lo que no diría que la implementación de todas ellas sea correcta. En sí, aparte de las armas, el juego es de lo más genérico que pueda existir en cuanto a jugabilidad. Pegas saltos, disparas, coges el drop del enemigo, el cual proporciona experiencia para subir niveles a las armas (lo cual lo considero un acierto, ya que nos hace ser más cuidadosos a la hora de recibir daño puesto que el arma que llevamos equipada baja de nivel), salud o cohetes para el lanzacohetes. 

En cuanto al apartado artístico, el juego luce fatal para mí. Es decir, me mostraba reluctante hacia la adquisición del título porque se veía insípido de cojones, pero bueno, quizás sólo fuese ese aspecto, ¿verdad?  Spoiler: no.

Referente a la historia, aquí es donde está el punto de inflexión. Cuando llevaba 2 horas de juego, me decía: "Bueno, pese a que el juego se note clónico en cuanto a mecánicas, se vea soso de cojones y los personajes parezcan de plástico, quizás sea porque aún no le ha dado tiempo a desarrollarse" Qué equivocado estaba. La premisa en sí no está mal. Si alguien viene y me dice que ha jugado a un juego que trata sobre unas criaturas que viven en una isla flotante, las cuales al tomar unas flores rojas se ponen hasta las cejas de speed y que son controladas por un malo maloso que se aprovecha de ellas y utiliza a estos especímenes para conquistar la superficie terrestre, podría considerarlo ligeramente interesante. O sea, el argumento es el tipiquísimo personaje tirano que se aprovecha de los más débiles para ejercer su poder, pero tú tomas el rol del héroe y junto al poder de la amistad y de tus cojines, serás capaz de derrotarlo y hacer que la paz reine. No obstante, se puede moldear lo suficientemente como para que pueda llegar a atraerme. Pero... ¿adivináis qué? No es el caso. 

La historia se desarrolla sacándose personajes de los cojones de los cuales ni siquiera se vuelve a saber nada, no importa cuál de los tres finales escojas. Creo que la relación que se establece entre algunos es antinatural y sin sentido (excepto con Sue, que entiendo que se llegue hasta tal punto porque desde el primer momento te presentan su actitud y personalidad). Lo mejor, sin duda, son los tres finales. A cual peor, por el amor de Jesús de Nazaret. O sea, me parecen tan tan tan tan ridículos que no sé si tomármelos como humor involuntario. O sea, lo poco que construye el juego en cuanto a vínculos en personajes, se lo pasan por las axilas. Lo mejor es que los personajes de la historia se lo pasan aún más por las axilas y el nivel de sudapollismo que alcanzan por no saber la situación del resto de compañeros me resulta aún más jocoso. Sólo me viene a la cabeza el final de The Departed, pero lo mejor es que Cave Story lo hace elevado al cubo. Maravilloso.

Por si fuera poco, tengo que hablar (sin spoilers) del final y de su dificultad. He de decir que lo jugué en modo normal. El grueso del transcurso del videojuego se me hizo correcto. Es decir, hay bosses que me mataron una o dos veces, pero que al pillarle el truco son asequibles, pero cuando llegamos al final, el juego coge la curva de dificultad y le pega un subidón que parece el pico de tensión que alcanza un corazón a 400 bpm. O sea, ¿me estás diciendo que tengo que hacer TOOOOOODO eso sin morir? Cuando completé la primera parte me dije, okay, probablemente haya algo más y me dejen guardar, pero al ver lo que me venía sin opción a poder guardar... qué queréis que os diga, me pareció injusto y con una dificultad artificial. Como ya en este punto estaba harto del juego, vi dos de los finales en YT (uno lo completé yo) y me ahorré no sé cuánto tiempo de frustación y la sensación de estafa que me hubiera dado al ver todo lo que había luchado para semejante basura. 

Una pérdida de tiempo que lo único que me hace es esbozar una sonrisa al recordar lo j o d i d a mente malo que es esto. Lo único que puedo rescatar es la banda sonora, la cual escucharé con la misma sensación que cuando recuerdo a un compañero de clase que me caía mal.

72676984.review:
This game is a good metroidvania type platformer that tries not go make you too many times around the entire map (something I always had a major gripe with all metroid titles).
As for good points, I have the following:
- Graphics are good most of the time (despite the limited colors I never felt hidden elements due to coloring weirdness or unrecognizable elements)
- There is a decent variation between areas to avoid repetition
- Weapon selection also gives some player choice and variety
- Story is... ok, nothing ground breaking, but good enough to keep you interested (although some story point plots are very random, because, game).
- 99% of the time is obvious where you have to go, even if you stop playing the game for a while and come back

As for the bad point I have the following:
- controller support is buggy. On my experience the best way make the gamepad (a ps4 gamepad) properly detected is to go to steam big picture, launch the game and select in the game input options. Still, if you happen to switch window to check something and you switch back immediately to the game window, gamepad won't work unless you switch first to big picture again and then switch to the game. Also, if you start without big picture the game resets the input
- the camera can be weird at times. Unlike games such as megaman and metroid, the camera is moving constantly instead of opting for a smooth lower movement and moving only at the end of the screen. I felt kind of irritated at times with this


Overral I think this is a good game and if you happen to want to have some metroidvania action then this is a go.

72585561.review:
The game doesn't have 4k support and will require you to change your internal resolution to 1920x1080p or lower, otherwise the screen will be stretched and won't be exactly to scale. 

Other than that the game is rather straight forward and fun, similar to Metroid but not entirely the same as it features a range of different weapons that you can use and upgrade by killing enemies and there is quite a few secrets to find, bosses to fight and levels to explore. The story is pretty basic and didn't personally interest me in the world or environment as much as it probably could but that's ok as it's a simple easy to follow plot with gameplay that is reminiscent of the NES era. 

The game's difficulty on normal mode (cause that's what I played on) hasn't many huge difficulty spikes, I'd recommend that you find all the upgrades in each area before going to the next, but for the most part I didn't find the bosses very difficult once I learned their movement patterns and attacks. 

The final boss on the normal ending was tricky and the controls made it more difficult but I reckon it would be easier with a controller as opposed to a keyboard. This game has multiple different endings I think 3 in total so that's an interesting addition to the game and it doesn't really hinder anything. 

I'd give this game a 7/10 it's been out since 2011 and this release could be tweaked with 4k support but overall if you can get it cheap it can be a fun 4-5 hour long game depending upon how many platformers you've played and how you find the controls. 

So yeah pretty good for being made entirely by 1 man.

Cave Story+ is a 2D metroidlike retro game in the vein of the NES sidescrollers.
And if you like those games it's fun enough even though the controls feel kinda floaty.
The story and characters are 100% japanese aka a bit weird but totally cute and the evil guys are just soooo evil.
The gameplay is that of a 2D sidescroller from the NES era with a little bit of Metroid sprinkled on top.
The difficulty, for the most parts, is pretty low except if you want the TRUE GOOD ENDING, then it's the typical japanese/indie bullshit with some obscure prerequisites which you would never, ever guess in your first playthrough, a pretty hard platforming section and then the final boss with multiple phases all without a save point in between.
It's not that hard to be honest and I would have probably done it if I had tried 3 or 4 more runs but I had better to do with the  15 to 20 more minutes of my life.
So yeah if you like or liked 2D sidescrollers from the NES era give this one a try but don't expect anything special.

71780450.review:
This is my absolute FAVOURITE game of all time and always will be. Here's why:

First off, for a game witch the word "story" in it's title, it conveys a great tale. The game begins with you -- an amnesic robot -- waking up in a mysterious cave. From then on, more is slowly revealed about the character you play as. Without spoiling anything: this is truly an amnesia tale done right as you connect with the protagonist when discovering all the secrets of this world with him. Anyway, Throughout your journey you will be encountering all sorts of characters with varied personalities and their own reasons to be on the floating island that you explore. Even all the bosses have motives and are distinctive in their own way.

Next up, I want to touch on the graphic and audio design of the game. This game released back in 2004 as a freeware game but it's oldness is NOT the reason for it's charming pixel graphics. I believe that the graphics were intended to look like old console games to make the game different or fill the player with nostalgia. This was an interesting choice since postmodernism was very rare amongst videogames at the time and it made Cave Story -- again -- unique. And the spritework is very well-made and natural anyway. Okay, now for the soundtrack... IT'S SUPER BRILLIANT! It adds so much atmosphere and fits super well wherever you are. There's heaps of bops and great tunes that are just a pleasure to listen to in free time as well.

Alright, now to address what the game plays like. I'd say the genre for the general gameplay is Metroidvania but then again, the game is pretty linear. There's also heaps of platforming challenges and enemies to face and-- Oh, right, the platforming! I just can't get over how good it feels to even JUMP in this game. It perfectly strikes the balance between floatyness and tightness. Aside from jumping, your other main move is shooting your wide arsenal of guns! Every weapon feels unique and different, and you'll always find yourself switching from one to another as a way of adapting to your surroundings.

To conclude: This game is an absolute MASTERPIECE and even replay value in the forms of multiple endings, unlockable challenges, and Steam achievements. But above all, I decided to review this game as it has the defining characteristic of what I believe to be an outstanding game: replay value from a game's sheer quality.

71594254.review:
If you can get past the floaty controls, Cave Story lives up to its reputation as the godfather of indie platformers and still stands as one of the most definitive in its class despite it’s age. 

I held off on buying Cave Story for the longest time, mostly because of the rumours that the publisher screwed Pixel, the dev, out of any royalties from the game.  After scouring the internet for any concrete evidence, this appears to be complete conjecture, and Pixel even confirmed on his Twitter that he receives royalties from Cave Story + .  I’m not saying this publisher is innocent or anything, but I couldn’t find any evidence in the case of Cave Story.  I did buy Pixel’s other game, Kero Blaster (different publisher), to make sure I was supporting the dev just in case.

Second, I was worried that, this being the iconic grandpa of the indie platformer/metroidvania/faux 16-bit movement that I love so much, I was worried that it wouldn’t live up to the hype.  Old games can often feel more like museum exhibits than anything else (looking at you KOTOR)…  

Well, luckily none of that was founded in anything but my own doubts and I was completely spellbound by everything Cave Story through at me.  The setting, the narrative, the secrets, the OST, the charm, the boss battles… it all just screams of that quality and focus that only really comes with single dev projects.  There really is just something magical about the way it all comes together, and while it certainly is an homage to the 16-bit platformers of yore, it doesn’t necessarily feel like a nostalgia trip.  If you like these kinds of games, this is definitely worth picking up.  My only real nit pick is the floaty controls, in that the whole game feels a bit like the ice levels from Donkey Kong Country.  So many of the times I died was coz I couldn’t get used to the floaty jumping or the constant skidding.  

All in all, this really is a masterpiece and I’m glad I eventually bit the bullet and got it.  Its got a lot of replay value too so I’m sure I’ll be dropping back in for more playthroughs, and can’t wait to get stuck into Kero Blaster as well.

Now, both New and Remastered soundtrack seemed to not fit well, the first being not even good remixes and the latter being very "arranged" where it doesn't feel like it's coming from a game but out of nearby Sega CD. But you can still use old, original graphic and music.

Translation is different from original fan-translation, but it's all just wording. Fans prefer the 'original'. Seem to be flawed in different ways. You can mod in original however.

New gameplay stuff are just extra modes and extra bugs. Which is cool, I guess, but I am on a fence since I heard that Nicalis are literally indie EA.
Sure, difficulty select and three save slots tho. Easy is way too easy, I heard, Hard is CBT from what I read.

What I want to say, is that it won't hurt you to just play freeware original. Which I will, using Cave Story Engine 2, where it has widescreen, can pick between 60 or 50 fps and has VSync and smooth scrolling which ought to help with jerkyness of 50fps on certain setups.

EDIT: Actually, it seems like it has Wind Fortress that you can unlock as extra, which was scrapped zone that doesn't fit to current Cave Story line but maybe cool as a bonus? Uhhhh, this is now a harder decision. Ah well, will just YouTube it, still not wanting to support Nicalis right now.

Uhhhh, if I start not buying games based on that, I will have to really rethink my purchase choices. But legal freeware version exists so.
Game being 20% faster than (possibly) intended is still my main issue as semi-purist.

70894356.review:
I would very highly recommend Cave Story+ to anybody who is a fan of shoot-em-up games and platformers in general. I'd consider myself pretty adept with video games in general but I've never dipped my feet extensively into platformers that much and would thus not claim to be an expert at them, but more slightly above average. There are three difficulty levels: easy, normal, and hard. I went through two full playthroughs on normal, and I will say that Cave Story gave me lots of trouble more than just a handful of times. And there are a few specific parts of the game which saw me replaying sections at least ten times, and one of those (optionally) over 50 times.

With that said, I never felt like I died due to some random bullshit. Although it is annoying to replay entire sections and segments before boss battles and having to go through sequences and dialogue multiple times instead of skipping to where I was before I died (what a game like Celeste handles perfectly), I would say that it's still not an entirely bad thing as it encourages me to play smartly and master a segment so I don't mess it up. Cave Story is very much a game that requires you to "get good" so to speak, but it's good to know that even the hardest sections aren't impossible.

Two of the greatest facets of this game are its soundtrack and its replayability. Have you ever played through a game and had its soundtrack stuck in your head for days? Cave Story for sure did that to me. With that in mind, the game gives you options to see original graphics, new graphics, the old OST, an one made for the Nintendo DSi version, and a new "remastered" version that was made when this game released for the Wii. In my opinion, the DSi version (titled "New") is objectively worse in every way, and I could not recommend it. The remastered version attempts to stay true to the tone of the original, opts for more-instrumental music instead of the chiptune-based original. While I would say that the "Remastered" one is quite good and some of the songs are excellent, I would honestly still recommend playing through with the original OST. This game did not release during the peak of 8-bit and 16-bit games where music from that time period was a result of the limitations of the systems they were on (albeit it was still great), but released later on and created this way to sound like that specifically. In my opinion, however, I still prefer the new graphics setting to the old, as it is more or less very similar to the original but with higher resolution sprites and textures. It's safe to say that the Original OST is far superior to the others and for a first playthrough, at least, would recommend the new graphics with the original OST. It's really hard to convey just how great the OST is but I'll say that it's really up there as one of my favorites of all time. 

The last thing I'd wish to say about Cave Story is that I appreciate it's extremely-high replayability. It is quite possibly the only game I can recall instantly beginning a new playthrough of right after finishing it. Without spoiling anything, I'd like to offer a tip for a first playthrough. Read reviews to perhaps figure out if you want to buy this game, but try not to read any walkthroughs or spoilers. Most of the segments require you to master them, and their solutions aren't typically too out of the way, so it should not be too difficult. 

Once a first playthrough is finished, read a walkthrough or perhaps look up what secrets you might have missed and begin a second playthrough. This might seem lame or like a cop-out but I genuinely recommend that as the best way to play this game and you'll be able to squeeze maximum enjoyment out of as much playtime as possible. You will be surprised as to how much a large portion of the game's gameplay is altered significantly based on specific choices you make that you'd perhaps have to do out of your way to do.

Once you do a third playthrough, perhaps scale the difficulty to Hard (or Normal if your first or second were on Easy) and begin again. I myself have not tried that yet, as it seems to be pretty masochistic, but I gladly hope to do so someday. There are also some cool challenge stages available which I enjoyed.

To reiterate, Cave Story is a fun game with great core gameplay, elevated up by some of its unique gameplay quirks and great replayability, as well as a fantastic score and I would not only recommend it but put it into a category of "Must-Plays" for anybody that is a fan of story-driven action platformers.

68959726.review:
Cave Story+ is probably the best retro-style metroidvania developed post-2000. It might have come a moment too late, but its style, story, and level design are so instantly classic and original that it is well worth playing.

Cave Story+ is an enhanced version of Cave Story, and it can be played also on the DS, Switch and Wii. The original can be played for free on PC. It's a 2D metroidvania that has many story elements and twists in an evolving landscape of play. Levels seem linear and then branch out and connect. It avoids repetitive labyrinthian style and includes super mario-era jumping/platforming with a variety of weapons that level up after collecting currency from killing or level down from getting hurt. There are life and missile upgrades like Metroid, and alternative endings (3). It should be no surprise that Cave Story+ be classically great!

68921448.review:
Cave Story+ is a classic 2D side scroller game in the vein of Metroid or Castlevania. You follow the adventures of a mysterious robot on his quest to save the rabbits from the evil Doctor. The story is fine, but not overly compelling, but the game play is great. You get a variety of unique weapons that are all upgradeable as you defeat enemies, but lose effectiveness as you take damage. This creates unique game play decisions, especially when confronting new enemies. I don't know how many times during a boss battle I would start with one gun which i preferred, got hit a few times, and then needed to switch guns due to leveling down after I take a hit. Fun mechanic that kept me on my toes! Finally, the graphics are very unique and the music is amazing. Each new zone has a catchy tune to it that really helps immerse you in the level.

In terms of downsides, I did get frustrated at times with the saves. An autosave feature could have helped relieve that issue, seeing as I would get pretty fall along in a level and then die and have to play it all over again. This is a minor issue though, and overall this was a very enjoyable game that kept me coming back for more.

67726345.review:
I give it thumbs up, but it's definitely not for everyone.
It's obvious that a lot of love went into Cave Story(+). There is a story, there are dozens of secrets, three endings and so on. More importantly, the fundamental gameplay of running, jumping and shooting just works very well. The weapon power-ups are implemented in a fun way, you can perform power jumps with the machine gun etc.
My main gripe with Cave Story is that the distribution of save points is just badly done. Sometimes there are three in a row but there's usually none before a boss fight. Which means that if you fail (and you will), you need to traverse several rooms full of enemies and tricky jumps, and then endure lots of dialog (which you can speed up, but not skip) to try again. Meh.
Personally, I also didn't like the "skating" of the main character. I know this is a thing in early console jump and runs, but I personally like games where the character stops moving when I release the key/button. Also, considering the different decisions you can make (willingly or not), some save game management would have been nice.
About the secrets, different endings etc.: while it's great they are there, I still consider it bad design that the best ending requires you to omit certain unsuspicious actions without giving you _any_ hint.
There are also technical issues. Firstly, the (mandatory) scaling on widescreen monitors cuts of a good part of the upper and lower screen rendering the game unplayable since you can't see the tunnel at the bottom in the egg corridor. Forcing the game to run at 640x480 (through Win10 options) works, but stretches the display horizontally if your monitor can't compensate. For the original version, this might be discussable but for the reworked "+" version, this is just a No-Go. The game also crashed on me when I finished the machine gun challenge.
Last but not least, there is the final boss fight (normal ending) which actually consists of three boss fights in three rooms without any possibility to save or restock. It's not totally surprising that only about 20% of players seem to have reached the normal or best ending of the game. Actually, I guess the percentage would be even much lower if this game attracted anybody else than people who actually like this kind of game. So 80% of players who like this kind of game failed to reach a proper ending. Hmm.
Side note for the desperate: there's a file called profile.dat where the maximum and current life energy are stored at offsets 0x1C and 0x20 and the max/current rockets at offsets 0x58 and 0x5C. Just saying.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#353 out of 612)... it's time for Cave Story+.

Perhaps the quintessential indie platformer, Cave Story's simple, minimalist visuals belie a brilliantly designed gem of a game. Infused with humor, Cave Story perfectly balances platforming, exploration and (simple) combat -- with a great deal of variation in each aspect. That said, the difficulty curve can be a bit steep, and probably won't be very appealing to fans of more causal platformers. If you give Cave Story a chance, though, there's a lot to love here: it's one of those games you can return to again and again over the years and consistently discover something new or fresh about it that you'd never noticed before.

Note: Also played don Nintendo 3DS.

In terms of downsides, I did get frustrated at times with the saves. An autosave feature could have helped relieve that issue, seeing as I would get pretty fall along in a level and then die and have to play it all over again. This is a minor issue though, and overall this was a very enjoyable game that kept me coming back for more.

63970634.review: Cave Story+ has varied, original, and creative character design. These well-design fictitious characters are embedded into a compelling other-worldly setting and strung together with an interesting enough plot. In my opinion, the character and environment design elements are the best aspects of Cave Story+ and what has made the title truly stand out. On top of this, the gameplay is great. Taking on the role of a bot suffering from amnesia, you explore a variety of small levels connected via the hub world. Within these levels, you utilize a handful of projectile weapons, which all feel great to use, and gun down, once again, a solid range of well-designed enemies. In addition, these levels are engaging to maneuver and the missions which require the player to gather specific items help incentivize exploration of the zone to its fullest. Lastly, the boss battles are enjoyable enough with rather simplistic attack patterns. 62233710.review:
Cave Story is a near-perfect masterpiece of a video game. Largely credited as the father of indie games because of it's massive success with a one-man dev team, Cave Story earned that title through its wondrous game design. It's incredibly replayable, enjoyable, and challenging, TLDR: Pick it up if you have the cash or scrounge for the freeware version. 
Cave Story's gameplay is a combination of 2D-platforming and shooting, most easily comparable to the Metroid and Megaman series. The game offers roughly 10 different weapons to choose with, all of them changing drastically with every level up. Variety doesn't end with the guns because there are tons of distinct enemies and bosses to fight. Every fight in Cave Story is also a fair fight. If you die, it's your fault. Some of the maps are extremely challenging and satisfying to beat, like Hell, the Last Cave, and the boss gauntlet near the end of the game.  And those difficult levels aren't thrown at you immediately. Cave Story gives you plenty of time to learn the mechanics. Overall, it's best described as a difficult, yet satisfying 2D platformer/shooter.
The soundtrack is something to gush over. There are several marvelous chiptune songs to enjoy. The Balcony and Main Menu themes are some of my personal favorites. Just the joyous and upbeat nature of the soundtrack is enough to get me playing again. 
Story-wise, Cave Story's plot is simple while also complex enough to keep the player interested. I certainly wasn't expecting this cutesy pixelated game to have serious consequences and so many character deaths. You have to work your damn hardest to save one of the game's most iconic characters. There are numerous points where you can screw and get that character killed, but for the most part, it's something you can have the foresight to think about.
My only complaint about Cave Story involves the True Ending and an item called the 0.8 Booster. There's a point in the game where a character you know falls into a pit. 99% of players are going to jump in that pit to rescue him. If you decided to avoid the pit for some reason, the gap you have to jump over is massive, so it's still likely you'll fall in. If you fall in that pit and talk to that character, he dies and you lock yourself out of the true ending. What's even worse is that if you do that, you can't save a different character because an essential item just won't spawn. There is no connection to that item and the other character. You would have no idea the two were connected unless you looked it up. 
In short, Cave Story was fantastic. With its phenomenal game design, an amazing soundtrack, and a decent story, it's certainly worth playing. Just keep in mind the stupid locks behind the True Ending.

However there are drawbacks to this release on Steam. Cave Story came out in 2004 and was developed by a single man for free with that version still being available on the website. The only thing that separates this version between the original free one is that Cave Story+ costs a decent $15 and only has a select few new game modes and remastered music tracks. There is almost nothing that separates this version from the original which makes you wonder why it cost's a decent amount. You'd be better off downloading the original. Despite being a Steam release there is no workshop support for mods and whatnot, that might be me being picky and a high expectation from such an old game written in whatever coding language.

TL;DR if you really want to play this go download the original game instead of this release, as said by many other reviewers. I enjoyed the game and its characters before I bought this version, so I ended up buying it anyway.

I'm surprised I haven't reviewed this game yet.
This game is a masterpiece, when a game says it's got overwhelmingly good reviews, it's probably cause it's really good.
Everything about this game ranging from its story, gameplay style, music (the music is definitely one of the best OSTs out there. It's a super neat "Run and Gun" metroid-vania type of retro shooter, definitely with its own easy and challenging features, when the game gets too easy for you there are a couple other modes that will keep you busy (especially hard mode, I haven't beaten it yet, and it looks like a nightmare).

The story is nice and linear in the worlds you travel to but then you can also travel back and forth and collect secrets, and there are 3 different endings to this game, so some choices can make a difference.

Even if it is a masterpiece, there is one little thing that might get annoying around the third playthrough or so, is that through the story there is a lot of going back and forth to collect items for this that, but I guess that's just a big part about how you're supposed to progress so I can't really complain much about that.
This game is as good as it gets if you like retro platformers.

The shooting mechanics have to be my favourite, every gun apart from the rocket launcher has no cooldown so it's very satisfying to mow down bosses by jitterclicking, it's very trigger-happy friendly, and again, all guns except the rocket launcher doesn't actually use any ammunition either, so, yeah, even the shooting is skill based.

I am going through my third playthrough (after accidentally losing my save data for my second run and almost beating Ballos, because I reset my laptop without a backup).

This game doesn't need a very good computer to run, it's not very demanding in terms of RAM either.

I love the music, please play this game, it's worth your time, 100% (unless you don't like platformers, then that's okay).

60367143.review:
A nice side-scrolling shoot 'em up with a decent (if a bit bonkers) story. Lots of hidden upgrades, weapons, and upgrades for those weapons, and a unique levelling system for your guns that I can confidently say that I've never seen anywhere else.

You may be wondering why this review is negative, then. To answer that, I have one thing to say; Colourblindness.

Beware if you buy this game and you have achromatopsia (Monochromatic Colourblindness) or any monochromatic variation of colourblindness. It will be unplayable. The Egg Corridor is alright; even if a few enemies do end up getting the jump on you or seemingly appear out of nowhere, you can still triumph with a bit of memorisation and random shooting. My main gripe comes from the aptly named "Final Cave". I've been told by a friend that it's all red enemies, with a black background and grey platforms. To me, and possibly to some of you, this cavern is a smudgy, blurry mess of platforms, some of which you can pass right through and more still that have deadly spikes attached to them. Now, with more memorisation, this would be easy enough; blindfolded playthroughs of games *do* exist. The problem comes from the randomly-spawning red enemies that blend in almost seamlessly to the background as well as a final gauntlet that will instantly kill you if you make even the slightest misstep.

I really enjoyed my time with the game, even if I struggled a bit. With a bit of hard work and some luck, it is possible to play Cave Story, but do know that you will not enjoy it without a bit of extra work.

I find that Cave Story plays better on mobile platforms, like the Switch, than it does on PC. That being said, I adore this game. The story is top-notch, the visuals- in my opinion- single-handedly started the trend of indie developers using retro-era graphics to tastefully integrate an element of nostalgia into their games. The gameplay is perfectly tuned to be the right amount of difficult, yet fair, with a sort of "variable learning curve" that will challenge players new to the platforming genre, while keeping things interesting to platforming veterans. With how much I've played this game, I have only found one flaw, and it's a very minor one: the game feels a little too floaty. The jumps, the travel time of your shots, and walking, all have an airy feeling to them that may make them feel as if they're lagging slightly. That being said, it barely impacts the experience, and by the end of the second level I was largely accustomed to the controls. A lot of players complain about how difficult the true ending is to achieve without a walk-through, however, I find that the true ending requiring the player to explore specific areas of the game to be quite refreshing- especially for a metroidvania game.

56669324.review:
This game is very well made, it has came a rather long way for an old indie game that has been ultimately developed by one guy in the span of half a decade, but to be honest, it is anything but perfect.

To start off with the story, it's ... well it's alright but kind of boring for the most part, It hints at you that it is not as simple as it seems and there's something deeper to it's history, that is fine, but I would prefer it if the game would show more, rather than tell through a text box.

The art style and music is pretty good, although the characters are a bit too one dimensional and boring, personality wise. I don't really know why that is, but the characters never seem to acknowledge the main character's efforts at all, as if he never existed. So most of the time you just awkwardly stand there, as you watch the game play itself.  

And now if I could describe the gameplay and platforming aspect in a sentence and you probably won't like the way I put it: I would call it a cheap version of Mega man and Metal Slug, with the floatiest controls I have ever experienced, I know it's dumb but Jesus, the way the main character jumps in this game, it's like he just floats upwards as if he's as light as a feather and then when he descends, he just flumps down extremely fast, as if he weighs as much as a school bus. In short, the controls are way too floaty, slippery and imprecise.

I might have complained a lot in this review but all I wanted to do is point out that this game has flaws, but these flaws are just too prevalent to make this game an enjoyable one. It's a mixed bag for me.

5.5/10

54896203.review:
Cave Story can be considered the first 'Modern Indie' game and I think it's well made, and has obviously high production value (especially being the + version and all), but I just think it has some outstandingly poor design choices, not a lot of them but the ones that are present ruin it for me.

The biggest one for me is the level design, and the forced back-and-forth in the zones, you'll reach the end of a level, only to find out that you need a macguffin, in which other macguffins are needed to make the one macguffin you need, often spending one just to get the other, forcing you to backtrack and get the one you used to get the other part for it. It's incredibly repetitive in that aspect, with the overly linear zones in the game (Most levels being almost completely horizontal. the second biggest problem is that It's not even a metroidvania, like everyone claims it is. What makes this NOT a metroidvania is that you gain abilities (as in weapons, powerups, etc that you can use to traverse, destroy, alter the environment or the enemies around you, or increase you agility in such a way that you can overcome obstacles, among other things.) the reason I can see that people say this is a metroidvania, is that you go back and forth in these incredibly linear levels, some of these levels being incredibly awkward to travel through, especially with your Zero-Gravity jump, which I feel like has an incredibly awkward Vertical-Horizontal distance ratio, feeling a bit unwieldy to use, especially during tight platforming sections, often with traps that instantly kill you.

This game's story and characters are really good though, especially the Mimigas and Curly, who are incredibly cute, I don't think the lore is deep but I do think that it is incredibly entertaining, if not a little generic. 

If you're looking for a metroidvania, look elsewhere, this aint one. 
If you're looking for a good story, look elsewhere as well.
If you're looking for a game where you can play as a cute robot. You found the one.

Cave story is incredibly important to the history of gaming, I just don't find it too fun.

I consider this to be one of the best games that I've ever played! I've gone through it once in 2014, then in 2018 I returned to get the hardest ending, and then again for more achievements, and beating Ballos in under 6 minutes (or however it was). 
It has a unique mechanic where your gun gets upgraded by how much XP you collect from fallen enemies, but if you get hit you lose (besides HP) the upgrades! There is an exception.
The story is unique and interesting and memorable. Graphics are great (for this version; note that they are pixelated) and I love the original music. It is some of the most memorable music in gaming (again, not the Danny Baranowsky version, the original one, his sounds too much like the Super Meat Boy music).
Once again, this game has some very memorable bossfights, especially the 3 chained in a row (haven't seen anything like that before, in a game, and it was wonderfully implemented)!

54134773.review:
[h1] Opening thoughts	[/h1]
Cave Story is a great example of detail. There is always something new that you can find in the game to enhance your second, third, fourth playthrough and so on. The story is that of pure magic. There is no point in time that I wasn't submerged and there wasn't a time when my eyes were ever away from the screen. The story always found ways to throw you from your chair always being able to bring you back further into the gameplay than ever before. With items that change who you meet and who comes along with you.

[h1] Gameplay	[/h1]
The gameplay is also something to look at. There are different ways to use your weapons, and to upgrade them as the game goes on, and one of the best aspects of the game is that there are so many different weapons in the game. Even better there are other weapons hidden in all over the island that you are on. The enemies and the allies, all of them are fun to hang around, and try new strategies to getting around as the game progresses and as your hours grow.

[h1] Bosses	[/h1]
The bosses are sufficiently hard, and they will get you scratching your head at frustration at times, but beating them makes it all that more rewarding as the game goes on, and even better, you can find other ways to beat the bosses, which makes it really fun to play at multiple times. The bosses are fair in that remark and for the people that are saying it is a hard game to beat, I agree. But that’s what makes it a fun game to sit down to and listen to something in the background.

[h1] Art	[/h1]
The art in the game is really comforting. Late at night it is easy on your eyes, and early in the morning, its also welcoming to a groggy person trying to one shot it in one day. The artistic-ness also leaves you wanting to get out your pc and make a game of your own. At some point I realized that you could screenshot it at any point in time you could screenshot it and make a really rememberable background, its that crisp with its pixels, and it doesn’t leave you underwhelmed or anything of that sort.

[h1] Closing thoughts	[/h1]
I highly recommend this came to anyone who sees past graphics being the spotlight for the game, as the atmosphere, and the gameplay brings new light to my eyes and always is a game that I end up buying on all the systems that it becomes available. At first it is something to put all your attention too, you will do some googling, and then you will find stuff that you may have never even knew existed before, and that makes it mysterious in a way. A good way that is.

54112032.review: Cave Story is a jump'n'run'n'gun in the sense of the "Metroidvanias" (albeit more linear) with Mario-like controls (your character does not instantly stop). The graphics are adequate, the music is fantastic and the gameplay is pretty fun. There is a variety of guns for you to pick up and choose from, which can each be levelled up to increase their power (they delevel again when you take damage). You also only possess one life, but there are frequent save spots and health refill..machine...things...A lot of bossfights, characters to talk to and secrets to uncover (which I all missed, judging from the achievements list) give you more meaningful things to do other than just shooting baddies, which always respawn when you enter and exit a building. You can't really go wrong with it on sale.

There are a handful of fun weapons and unlockables that will require more than one playthough, fun and interesting yet brutal achievements that test the player harder than a Farewell from Celeste, and a lovely story filled with endearing characters. Cave Story is an incredible pixellated 2D platformer with a good story and 2 different endings, and is available for free online. 

Cave Story+ is the same, but, brings a new ending (my favorite too), challenges, 3 difficulties for newcomers, experienced people, and the hardcore people. It also gives you an option of listening to the old or new soundtrack and of playing with the original graphics or the new more polished ones, depending of what you like better. It also brings a new mode: Curly Story, where you play as Curly Brace, which is also my favorite character in the whole game, instead of Quote, although the game plays the same with a minor dialogue differences.

I definitely recommend it to everyone

51460085.review:
When I was 11 years old, I bought Cave Story from the Nintendo DSi Shop. It was a total blast and provided me with hours of fun. I didn't finish the game, and haven't touched it since. A friend of mine gifted me CaveStory+ here on Steam a few weeks ago, so I decided I would give the game another go and see how much I remember. Fortunately, I remembered almost nothing except for the fact that this game is truly a masterpiece. The controls, the artwork, the music, the gameplay, the bosses, the atmosphere, the story, everything had me really appreciating all the work and passion that would put into this game. So many little things I noticed, an example being how you're always introduced to new concepts in the game at a very basic level, before encountering the same enemy/idea later on where it's more dangerous. Lots of things to help the player learn and prepare ahead of time. I love this game, and I plan on playing it again.
I beat it in one sitting in approximately 7.8 hours. It was so, so good. I love this game. Excellent work.

I strongly recommend this game. If you have any doubts for any reason, watch some gameplay and I'm sure you'll be pleased.

50041021.review:
It's a Cave, and there's a Story.  Glad we covered all the important parts!

PROS: The story has a very 'lived in' feel to it.  Although you're important to the plot, you really drop in during the middle of things, leaving it to happen around you, rather than centered around you.  The metroidvania design of the game gives plenty of options for additional weapons and health, providing different ways to play, and the weapon level system gives more power and incentive to play without being hit to keep your weapons at their strongest.  The pixel art is very well designed, and charming to look at, and the soundtrack another wonderful touch, playing off the charming nature when needed, leaning to the creepy when used properly, and pumped up during the action pieces.

CONS: The controls feel very floaty, leading to many untimely deaths while trying to get used to the particular platforming the game requires of you.  Some parts of the game can also feel a little disjointed, whether it be through the sudden and sharp dark twists in the story, or the puzzle aspects that can be a bit too out there for someone to just stumble across (looking at you, Machine Gun/Spur and Booster 0.8/2.0).  By far the worst is the jarring difficulty spike the game decides to fall into during it's last segment.  Yes, the final areas of the game should be the most difficult, but the way this game handles it borders over the extreme.  This is made even worse on the harder difficulties, where most enemies can kill you in a single hit.  The additional bonus stages don't feel like they add anything other than more difficulty for players, giving little desire to go for the best ending.

ACHIEVEMENTS: This is a mess.  Getting S Ranks on the extra stages is such a small and tight window, as is Hard Mode and the True Final Boss.  But, if you want to complete this list, you need to be able to go in and change the launcher's code, because it wasn't programmed properly.  Don't do this, and that Best Ending run becomes completely waste.

FINAL: My feelings are quite mixed on this.  On the one hand, I love the game's design and story, but on the other, the odd decisions for better gear, sudden dark story turn, and ludicrous difficulty spike can leave a negative impact.  Although I recommend this in the end, be prepared for a Blood Stained Sanctuary of a trip going for completion.

49793928.review:
I like to describe Cave Story as a Shot Them Up that happens to feature gravity in a way that makes it also a platformer. Even if you dislike platformers, if you like shooters (specially SHMUPS) you will love Cave Story. The powerup system, the boss fights and the bullet patterns you have to avoid, all of it screams SHOOTER all over the place

Yes, there is some "rough edges" on the level design every now and them (specially at the First Cave) and some of the weapons seem much more like an experimentation than something a "professional" dev would put in the final game. But this game was not made by a professional, it was made by a true amateur. And that's a good thing. Amateur, in French (from latin amator) means LOVER.

Yes, indeed... You can feel the love in each level and the love you feel playing seems to have been put there pixel by pixel by Pixel (pun intended). Cave Story was made by a passionate gamer, and it shows. This is one of the first games to pop my mind when I think about what "indie" means as aesthetics. 

Besides the fictional story, if you pay attention you can see a very true story, the story of how Cave Story came to be. There are some earlier enemies and traps that, in a "normal" game would be transformed in patterns that would permeate the entire game. That doesn't happen. Instead, a lot of stuff introduced on earlier stages are let there as if the author had decided that they were not such a good a idea. Again, in a "normal" game, this "not that good" ideas would be stripped off. Instead, they aquire meaning of its own. And that's really refreshing.

In game design, things are supposed to have meaning when considered as part of a whole. In Cave Story, many things are there on their own. But then again, that's good! Because they also get to have MEANING on their own (guardian of the graveyard, I'm looking at you).

It's pretty much like a large book where some character seems like will have an important part in the story, but them he somehow vanishes and you are let wondering if the writer had something planned and changed his mind. Afterwards, when you think about that great book, you always remember that character despite the fact that he wasn't so important to the story after all.

This collection of fragments comes together  so neatly that it could not be done by a group. Not like this. This is an authors game. The pieces inevitably come together because they come from the same mind. There's something that only happens when designer, programmer, writer and artist are the same person. An this something is what I like to call "intent". This game has intent. It craves to be a shooter and insists on being a platformer whilist being an RPG. And accomplishes all that.

48408542.review:
This is one of the best metroidvania games I have ever played. It is an enhanced edition (2011) of an old game, but looks even older than it really is. Although the original (Cave Story, without the +) was released in 2004 it looks like it is an original NES game. It currently sells at around 15 euro on Steam, which is quite a lot of money for such an old game, but I guess a lot of effort went into the remastered  2011 version. I think the game is worth the full price.
The game was created by just a single developer, which makes the quality of the game all the more remarkable. The graphics look great, the music is superb. The character controls very well which makes platforming a breeze. The level design, intricate storyline and nice atmosphere of the gamer are one of its best qualities. There are a variety of weapons, upgrades, enemies, and lots of good boss fights. But wait, there is more! The game features multiple play modes and a bunch of alternate endings.
The game is not perfect though. There is a little too much backtracking involved for my taste. And the English names of some characters don't go well with these characters and feel out of place with the Japanese names of most other charactersare, this issue is quite typical for Japanese games: for instance one of the bosses which looks like a fridge is called Balrog, and one of the bunnies is called King. But these are all just minor issues that do not diminish the fun of playing Cave Story+.

48169128.review:
The time Cave Story was released in 2004 allowed the lone wolf delevoper to make a bigger impact on game culture than many small studios are able today. Gameplay that would be called unoriginal today, would be called revolutionary in the early 2000's PC gaming market. Who knew an "early 2000's" story could be so engaging?

This game is part of a group of few games from the "freeware-flash game" era from the early days of the Internet that stood the test of time. It's up there with other freeware games like Spelunky and N that set the stage for a huge amount of games that would come after. Cave Story was an instant classic, and it holds up today with tight controls, a great soundtrack and timeless graphics. Creative character development, and varied level and enemy design keep Cave Story feeling fresh...pretty much all the way through.

The real question is why I didn't pick it up sooner.

Using anything other than the original OST is earbleeding. The Bushlands track was so bad with the "new" OST that I ended up turning the music off for the rest of the game.
I don't like the art style, but that's personal opinion, obviously. I think it's a pretty ugly game, which I give slack to as it was made in 2004 by one person[?]. The remaster doesn't add much in that aspect though.
The gameplay really isn't anything to write home about. The whole game is rather easy on normal until the end, where the difficulty curve jumps like ten levels and makes you fight one of the most bullshit 4 phase bosses I've ever had the displeasure of battling, made EVEN WORSE on the true ending, where you have to complete a 3-5 minute obstacle course taking as little damage as possible and then battle a second, more bullshit 4 phase boss. And you have to redo the obstacle course every time you want another go at him. Every. Time.
The characters are bland and boring, most are just shitty little furries with nothing interesting to say. I saw that there was a better translation with more personality in another version of the game, but I didn't do any research into it, so I dunno more about it. You'd think a game named "Cave Story" would have a better story though.

I know I've said nothing good about it, but I tentatively give this game a 4/10. It could definitely be worse than it is, and some parts are genuinely interesting and fun. You know, as long as you trade guns with Curly. Otherwise, it's a really boring slog through a boring game that ends with an annoying slog through annoying bosses.

Don't @ me.

47557921.review:
[Check the end of my post for a bottom-line.]

Welp. I'd like to preface this by making clear that I love playing games at the highest difficulties. It's the only way I can enjoy games at this point. Keep this in mind, because I played Cave Story at the highest difficulty. Also, I'd like to make clear that the gameplay itself wasn't annoying. It's the same reason why I loved They Bleed Pixels and other such games at their highest. It's difficult as hell, but I enjoy that. That's not where my complaints lie when it comes to Cave Story.

What I've come to despise so greatly is the lack of proper game mechanics that would normally come as a prerequisite. Something that you'd usually take for granted; the ability to skip cutscenes. I hated this issue so damn much. I'm at the highest difficulty. I'm going to die countless times. So, why, for the love of all living things, must I have to physically keep mindlessly pressing buttons, for nearly a minute, mind you, before I can restart a boss fight? The only way I was able to make this remotely close to "bearable" was, by the supreme luck that I happened to own one, to use a gamepad with turbo functionality. Even then, every time you run the game anew, the game doesn't remember that you've watched this cutscene over twenty times already, and will default back to scrolling dialogue at a normal pace until you die for the "first" time, and only then, the scrolling is only marginally faster.

Again, I know I going to die countlessly. I understand this. I accept this. It's what makes it fun. Cave Story's dialogue sucked the fun right out of the room and left behind only tedium of demonic proportions. One of the things that makes something difficult, fun is the fact that once you fail, you have the option to get right back into the fight, right where you left off. Not Cave Story, though. It's like this; I own a kayak. I love kayaking. For a while, though, I didn't own a transportation rack for quick mounting to the roof of my car. I ended up just dropping this fun hobby until I bought one because of how much of a waste of time and energy it became to set it up. You had to bring this fifty-pound thing out to the car, put it on the roof, strap it down, double-check it's secure, drive to a lake, unstrap it, carry it off the car, put it in the water, tidy the straps and pack them in the car, then you're able to have fun in the kayak. Only except now you have to get back home. So, you have to drag the kayak back on top of your car, strap it down, drive off, unstrap it, pull it off the roof, pack the straps up, and drag it back up to the house. Wasn't that whole description just a pile of senseless monotony? Wouldn't it just be easier if you could just put it on the roof and go? That's this game. It doesn't have a roof rack. It's the definition of an inconvenience.

Also, you can't even restart in the same room you died in. You respawn at the save points. This normally wouldn't be such a problem, except for the fact that you die so often, and sometimes, the save location is a few screens away from your goal. Plus, for a game that uses bullet-hell mechanics, it uses pretty complex design. Your character will periodically bleed into the background and fall right out of your line of sight, especially if you're moving about quickly (otherwise known as the most inoportune time in the midst of a boss fight). Another funny quirk I've noticed is the lack of the ability to pause into settings. You have to exit the game you're playing first before you can access the main menu. It would also be pretty nice if you could lower the difficulty mid-game. You pick a difficulty, there's no going back. You gotta start a new game.

I'm sure a lot of people will defend the developer in the way of mentioning that it was just a game quickly built as a hobby/passion project. You're absolutely right. At one point, this game sure was free, even. As it is now, though, it costs ~fifteen bucks, has developed a substantial fanbase, and is now over ten years old.. Update your god-damned game, pixel.

//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

[BOTTOM LINE: tl;dr: hard game fun, un-skippable cutscenes bad. I'm sure these problems are all but superficial at lower difficulties, but this was my experience. Outside of all of that, though, it was a nice-looking game. I loved all of the character and world design. Somewhat of an interesting story, and certainly one I could become involved within. Sadly, though, I cannot bring myself to continue. I cannot bear to image how awful these problems become at later stages. Such a shame. I was really getting into it.]

\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\

(Aside: I stopped playing at berserked Tokoro. I got so damn close at a just a few pixels shy of the status bar. Oof).
