My review is not about 'Is Cave Story a good game?' (Because yes! it is!)
But I'd rather want to say if this remaster is worth buying?
(In case it's not clear yet, this game is a remaster of an otherwise freelance game available on the developers main page.
So the original game is actually free!)

So, while the game does have remastered the soundtrack and graphics, the main game actually plays the -exact- same way as the original did: No improvements of QoL, No hidden pathways, all the bonus content is available on the menu instead. So if you've already archieved all things in the original game, you can do it all over again through the non-skippable cutscenes.

However, just only the fact that it has different saves, and even an individual save for the challenging part. Is already what makes it worth buying it.

It has some more small features of it, the challenges been the most interesting of all. But the amount of extra content it has seems to be smaller than I had expected for the price.
It IS however a direct improvement of the original game though. So it has my upvote for that.
It's a bonus expansion for an already great game. But keep in mind that the game itself remains the same as the original, which is available for free.

[h1]Cave Story offers more than just a good story inside a cave![/h1]

I did play the game on my Classic Wii back in the days and loved every moment of it. This port however, got some extra content that is worth checking out. Mostly unlockable Game Challenges and Remastered music soundtrack, but you can also switch between different soundtracks(Original, New & Remastered) and graphics(Original & New) so you can choose the kind of mix that suits you while you play through the game and can be changed at any time in the main menu.

I don't want to go much into the story to spoil anything for anyone who haven't played it at all, but all I can say it is very good overall, along with couple of fun secrets to discover when you least expect it.

As for the in-game achievements, there are the ones that are outragously difficult to obtain if you're achievement hunting(they are possible, but jeez!) also at the moment one achievment is broken and won't trigger, but can be fixed with help of a guide someone made in the community hub. Easy fix, but kinda silly this port of the game didn't get fixed with a simple fix like this. 

Overall, for this Steam port of Cave Story, it has greater(I even believe the best) amount of content you can get out of it. Certain things I feel could've gotten a proper polishing here and there(like the broken achievement I mentioned above), but nothing too serious that would make the game crash or anything like that(it doesn't).
The game can get REALLY difficult at certain parts, so make sure you really practice up your platform & shooting skills as you play!

If you've never played this indie platformer classic and looking for something that can pack some extra challenge and difficulty from time to time(especially as an achievement hunter) with a great story to follow with few multiple endings, then I can gladly recommend this one!

45715557.review: This is one of those games where you turn it on and within two minutes you realize you're in for something special. It's essentially a minimalist side-scroller with some nice visuals and catchy music, but the best parts can't be put into words. 45713254.review:
This is another game that's been hyped up like crazy, but it's above average at best. To be fair, perhaps this was really good when it came out (2004). But now? It's just not that great.

Let's start with the positives.
	• Fun/Strategic guns: The game has a lot of unique guns that are just flat out fun to use. Other guns are interesting simply because they are strategically useful in certain situations.
		○ Bubbler: You hold the attack button to create a wall of bullets, useful for protecting yourself from weak enemies. Once you release the attack button, the bullets shoot out all at once, so it can be used like a shotgun for burst damage. I've never seen a gun like this before and it was really fun to use.
		○ Fireball: This shoots tiny fireballs downwards and then the fireballs travel for a while before disappearing. The ability to shoot bullets downwards was useful in a lot of situations even right up until the end game.
		○ Blade: This has very short range but if you hit an enemy it does a lot of damage and damages enemies in a decent radius for a lot of damage. This was useful for rooms where you couldn't snipe enemies from far away. It was also useful for enemies that had a lot of HP so it was dangerous to use the weaker guns while avoiding damage (since you would need to spend like 10 seconds avoiding the enemies' bullets while trying to kill them, whereas with this weapon they could die in like 2 seconds).
		○ Machine Gun: This shoots a lot bullets that do decent damage. What's interesting about this weapon is that you can shoot downwards to allow you to hover for a long time (due to the "recoil" of the weapon). This is useful both for platforming and fighting enemies. 
		○ Spur: You can charge this weapon up to shoot a laser beam that does the most damage of any weapon, travels across the screen, and pierces enemies. This was fun to use simply because of how overpowered it was xD
	• Fun movement: Near the mid/end game, you get an ability to "jetpack" in any direction after you jump. This was surprisingly fun because you could go up, right, then up again. It's hard to explain, but the freedom of movement this ability provided was really awesome.

Now onto the negatives:
	• Minimal exploration: This is a VERY barebones Metroid Vania. This is very much a stage based game that you follow in a linear format. Hell most of the stages are accessed from a computer in the "Hub World" that allows you to teleport to various places (i.e. the world isn't connected). The only reason it gets to be called a Metroid Vania is because there's some back-tracking near the end game in order to get the best weapon in the game. So wow you get to explore/backtrack ONCE.
	• EXP levels for guns: In this game, guns have EXP that you get from picking up EXP after killing enemies. Guns start at level 1 and max at 3. However, if you get damaged, guns lose EXP and they can de-level (i.e. you can go from 3-->2). What the hell was the point of this? I originally thought that the developer wanted to create difficulty by encouraging players to not get hit. However, at the mid/end game you get the Spur which can't be de-leveled. So in the most difficult part of the game, for all practical purposes the game throws this mechanic out the window. Therefore, it just creates an unnecessary grind to the early/mid game. If you get damaged, you need to waste time farming enemies for EXP to max out your gun again. It would've been so much better for these upgrades to be permanent and for them to be something players FIND (i.e. actually use the god-damn Metroid Vania tag). This would've been so much fun because when guns level up, it is VERY noticeable and makes a big difference. Ah well.
	• Endgame: The end game is so god damn bullshit. This game has 2 endings (well 3, but let's focus on the 2). In the first ending, the game ends at a certain point and everything is not all that hard and provides a fair level of challenge. However, in order to get the best ending, you need to go through a lot of bullshit. You need to go through a pain in the ass platforming section with a boss at the end (no checkpoints in between). Later on you need to fight 4 bosses in a row (no checkpoints in between). Lastly, you need to go through 3 platforming sections, the 2nd with enemies RANDOMLY spawning and pieces of the ceiling RANDOMLY falling on you, followed by a boss, followed by the last boss with 4 phases (no checkpoints in between). Noticing a pattern? The developer was incapable of creating an interesting boss that's difficult to beat, so instead he just decided to test the players' endurance by throwing as much as possible at you without giving you time to rest. Keep in mind that these platforming sections can take like 5-10 minutes to beat so you're waiting 5-10 minutes before facing the boss. This isn't a fun type of difficulty because when I beat the game, I wasn't going "YES, I BEAT THAT SUNOFABICH". I was going "Phew, finally it's over". 

There's a story, but it's a classic good vs. evil type thing. Nothing special. I didn't care about any of the characters or what was going on or whatever.

So yea overall the game definitely had fun abilities and overall movement, so the game had a strong foundation. However, other areas such as exploration, annoying upgrade mechanic, and bullshit difficulty negatively impacted the experience. Like I said, above average game at best. This game has some things going for it. Other things, not so much.

I played the original cave story on the wii and the nintendo DS, and it was probably one of the best games to play on the wii/DS. I bought this game as I see it's an updated version of the game with new content, and I recommend this game. 

However, BE WARNED. I've encountered a peculiar bug when playing this game, one that could potentially give this game a thumbs down. It's only happened to me on THIS game, never on any other game. I remapped my controls so that I could use the WASD keys to move and such, and for the first 5ish deaths or so, it seemed to be working just fine. However, I died on the Egg Corridor stage (or whatever it's called, the first area after you teleport into after you get out of the starting area) and when I died, my controls went back to arrow keys. Thinking this was weird, I tried remapping them back to WASD again. Turns out the game can remap your WASD and arrow keys and swap them. Your keys remain swapped until you unplug and replug your keyboard back in.

I have not been able to recreate this so far, and I have not found out what causes this or what the solution is. I can only hope the devs that published the steam release of this game read this and fix it. It might be a minor inconvenience, but I think it really hurts this game, even though it could be a masterpiece. 44645469.review:
CÓMO SE ME PUDO PASAR ESTA OBRA MAESTRA TODA MI VIDA!?

Cave Story es EL JUEGO INDIE por excelencia! Desarrollado por Studio Pixel (Daisuke "Pixel" Amaya-sama), este sencillo y a la vez complejo juego "Metroidvania", nos pone en el papel de un robot sin nombre que despierta en una cueva sin recuento de cómo llegó allí. En esencia hay que salir de esta cueva, pero muy temprano somos transportados a una aventura que crece y se desarrolla tanto como las cuevas que se descubren, encontrando nuevos enemigos, nuevos aliados, y un montón de secretos que descubrir, y donde todo al final vale la pena sin importar la dificultad y longevidad del juego.

Esta versión es la segunda remasterización del título indie del mismo nombre, en esta versión se incluye todo lo de la primera remasterización además de un Nivel Extra para los que buscan la historia más completa (y MÁS difícil!), también incluye un modo especial para jugar con otro personaje, y varios desafíos adicionales con oportunidad de grabarlos para compartir el mejor tiempo con todos los jugadores del mundo.

Todo lo que tiene este juego es grandioso! Los gráficos "Pixel" art tienen un montón de detalles muy bien dibujados, la música y sonido sacan todo su potencial (y para los jugadores de la primera versión: el Soundtrack original está incluido!), y la dificultad es desafiante sin ser demasiado injusta, con múltiples opciones para los diferentes tipos de jugador.

Pero el mejor punto para mí es la Historia, simplemente es la mejor parte del juego: aventura, comedia, drama, suspenso, algo de terror, todo se reúne en la que puede ser una de las mejores historias, no solamente de los indies, sino de todos los videojuegos de todos los tiempos! Todo esto creado por una sola mente, y al igual que ZUN, Toby Fox, Studio MDHR, y otros tantos genios independientes que han dado sus historias a conocer con todo su esfuerzo, el mundo de los videojuegos del futuro ahora les pertenece a ellos!

Sin más que decir, recomiendo este juego para los amantes de los Metroidvania, de los juegos indie, de las buenas historias, de los plataformeros...Este juego no los decepcionará nunca, ni aunque caigan miles de veces!

44302032.review:
22.08.2018. Game #59

It has been well over a month since my last review. The reason for this is … that I’ve become a father. Yeah, apparently, after you become a parent you have less time for games. Who would have thought? 

[h1] I can't believe I haven't played this game earlier [/h1]

The sad thing is that Cave Story isn’t even that long of a game and it shouldn’t have taken me more than a few days to beat. Finally, after a month not even turning on steam, turning on steam and running to the baby’s room, actually booting “Cave Story” but running to the baby’s room because she was crying and, very rarely, actually playing “Cave Story”, I was able to finish this little game.

Cave Story is a sweet little game. When it first came out, I remember it being called “The best Super Nintendo game never released”. Cave Story certainly looks like a Super Nintendo game boasting a nice 2D platformer with 16 bit graphics as well as some 16 bit music. 

Now, when I heard the term Super Nintendo game, I thought about a platformer, not a particularly long one, with some nice music, creative enemies and a lot of jumping. Cave Story is all that and much more.

[h1] Save the cute little bunnies from the evil doctor [/h1]

Cave Story takes place in a *GASP* cave… that’s floating on an island??? Whatever, it’s not really important. What is important is what is actually going inside this floating island cave. You arrive as a robot with a wiped out memory on to the island and immediately the bunny like creatures that inhabit this island start avoiding you. You quickly learn that the Bunny creatures, known as the Mimiga, have been slaughtered in the past by killer robots like the one you are playing as. Seeing how you don’t feel the urge to slaughter the poor innocent bunnies, you decide to help them.

What follows is a surprisingly well made and a bit dark story. The bunny people start getting kidnapped by a man known only as “The Doctor” who wishes to use them in his evil experiments. He does this by making them eat red flowers which makes them go berserk. You, along with a few friendly NPCs must save the Mimiga race from the evil Doctor. While my description isn’t doing the story any justice, it is surprisingly well written, especially for what appears to be a Super Nintendo game.

[h1] Great controls [/h1]

But SNES games were never much about the story, right? What is the gameplay like? How is the jumping? How are the weapons? Well, I am happy to say that everything is just fine ‘n’ dandy.

Jumping and platforming feels responsive. It took me very little to get used to the momentum and the jumping and I generally didn’t have too many problems moving my character around. There are quite a few death traps that can kill you instantly during your platforming endeavors, however, the game hosts a generous amount of save points so most deaths shouldn’t lead to too much frustration.

[h1] The weapon system is phenomenal [/h1]

What’s really awesome about this game are its weapons and the weapon progression system. Since you are an ex-killer-robot, you are able to use a variety of firearms. Each weapon you collect can be leveled up three times. The higher the level, the more damage you do (DUH!). At first it seemed really easy to level up weapons and I thought that the system was broken, but then I started getting hit by some enemies and I realized that my weapon was losing experience. While this seems frustrating, it’s incredibly fun and challenging the level up your weapons and keep them from down-leveling. You start playing the game more carefully and carefully considering many upcoming moves that you make because not only does taking damage cost you precious hit points, but it might also cause your weapon to power down. Again, don’t be intimidated by this weapon system. It works great and more importantly, it’s a lot of fun. 

Speaking of weapons, you will be using them to kill a bunch of enemies. There are quite a few types of enemies in this game. Most of them are cute creatures like frogs, slimes, bugs, skeletons, etc. Each zone in the game has its own enemies and its own boss. Boss fights can seem intimidating but they are all about picking the correct weapon and not getting hit. If you throw yourself at a boss you will be left with little health and downgraded weapons which will make the fight a lot harder than it needs to be. If you instead tread carefully and fire when the boss is exposed, you will be able to win easily most boss fights. Seriously, I cannot praise the weapon system enough.

[h1] I guess it's a metroidvania but it's mostly just liner progression... and there is nothing wrong with that [/h1]

Cave Story, by definition, plays like a Metroidvania styled game, but I would disagree with that… at least a little bit. While you can go back to the zones you previously visited and while there are power ups (both weapon, health and missiles), backtracking in this game is kept to a minimum. Only once did I need to backtrack and only once did I get lost without knowing where to go next. Other than that, the game more or less plays like a linear 2D platformer, which is fine as well. What I am trying to say is: while this game is TECHNICALLY a Metroidvania game, you will play it in a very linear way.

[h1] Really catchy music [/h1]

The music is just amazing. The title theme is very catchy and the rest of the music is just great. Not once during my entire play through did I find a level theme I didn’t like and considering that the game uses 16 bit music, this is a very impressive feat.

[h1] A great game [/h1]

My only regret is that I never was able to finish this game up until now because Cave Story is a fantastic game. It’s simple, it’s short, it was made by just one guy and it’s a lot of fun. If you enjoy 2D platformers or metroidvania games, you will have a great time with Cave Story.

Now I wonder if it will take me another month to finish playing my next game.

Next game: Chivalry: Medieval Warfare

44012317.review:
[h1]A great game for anyone![/h1]

Cave Story is about a robot from the surface who awakens in a cave. Unaware of the situation the robot begins to explore his surroundings and soon meets the Mimigas, a rabbit/bunny species, that are trying to stop the doctor and his minions from taking over the world with the power of the red flowers.


Cave Story is a platform-adventure that requires you to use the right weapon for the right occasion. Weapons can vary from a peashooter, a missile launcher or a bubble gun that seems silly but when it reaches level three then it can perform some good damage over time. By killing enemies and certain bosses they will drop these yellow triangles which are experience points to level up your guns. Just be careful, because if you get hit then your guns lose experience points. Enemies can also vary from different types, from the flying insects that swarm you or bouncing blobs that try to jump and
butt stomp you or shoot small projectiles.

Throughout the game, you will find life upgrades and missiles upgrades to increase your survivability chance, these upgrades can be found tucked away in certain areas. It helps to explore the area and get everything you can get. Although experienced players don’t necessarily need to get everything as the game can be relatively a smooth pass till end game. Newcomers are recommended to get every health and missile upgrade as the end game can be tough for casual players. Some enemies become speedy and hard to hit while dealing a substantial amount of damage. As well the extra obstacles that can be in the player’s way. If you are having an issue with your guns losing a lot of experience points, then try to find the arms bearer as it halves the experience loss from your guns. 

If you find the loss of health too much, then try replaying the game on an easier difficulty. Easy mode is great for newcomers to the platform-adventure genre, but experienced players should give normal mode a try as it is a good challenge. Hard mode is recommended for hardcore players as you go throughout the game with only three hit points and you lose access to the missile launcher; by end game, you can find a life upgrade to boost your health to a maximum of eight.


My first experience with Cave Story was back when homebrewing the Wii was popular and one of the games I got was Cave Story. I enjoyed every aspect of exploring and finding goodies, defeating enemies in pulse-racing battles, and the joyful and emotional music tracks. Each location is straightforward and simple that your path is mostly linear, you can get a map system early on which reveals the map of the area, but I never used it since the areas were so small and straightforward. I played on easy mode for the Steam achievements and switched to normal mood for a fun adventure. Hard mode was challenging since you take double damage and with not a lot of health, you are basically a one-hit-wonder. The game is also short even if you go for 100% but the game does offer different challenges and a chance to play as another character. With different things to do you can put in twelve to fourteen hours into this game if you are dedicated to doing everything.


Rating (out of 10) -
[list]
[*]Graphics: 8
- If you played the original version of Cave Story, then these upgrades are an enhancement. Better lighting and more colors really make this game vivid.

[*]Music: 7
- I preached earlier about the music but it’s nothing that I will hum or anything. It’s nice on the ears but not memorable with exceptions of the soundtrack for that plays during the menu screen and the final boss theme.

[*]Story: 4
- The story felt vague, while simple, there was a lot of plot holes and things that we never got context about. It feels like Cave Story+ could have been a sequel that is filling in those plot holes, but since that’s not the case then the story just feels vague.

[*]Content: 8
- The controls are simple with one button to shoot, one or two buttons to switch weapons, joystick or control pad to move, and the same joystick or control pad to interact with things. Shooting in any cardinal direction wasn’t bad at all but your character’s jump does feel floaty which could make some tight platforming difficult.

[*]Gameplay: 9
- I love games that make feel like I’m in a tense situation with many do or die moments. Cave Story+ fulfills that and my sense of exploration. Strategies to defeat enemies, platforming challenge and challenging boss battles make this game fun!
[/list]


Cave Story+ is a great game for those who are new to the platform-adventure genre. It will teach you things about exploring and strategizing in positioning your character with the right weapons to deal with any obstacle in your way. Despite the added features, I do feel the game could be better at $12 price tag for $14.99 it's not a bad deal.

43607142.review:
[h1] WARNING: ABRUPT DIFFICULTY SPIKE [/h1]

     I'm writing this review to warn prospective buyers that the ending of Cave Story contains a massive difficulty spike relative to the rest of the game.  Starting off, you have to go through a boss fight that is easily one of the two hardest in the game up to that point.  Afterwards, you have to fight two different forms of a different boss.  THEN, you have to fight another boss, while dealing with two different powerful enemies simultaneously.  This fight, in particular, is a nightmare of moving platforms and swarms of monsters.  It was as far as I got, and I only managed to chip off a little of the boss's health before dying.

     None of these fights had a save point after them, which I consider inexcusable.   Up until this point, the game's difficulty had been pretty sensible, and as far as I can recall, you only ever fought one boss at a time before getting another save.  Even the final level before this boss gauntlet, which was obviously meant to be challenging, only took me an hour at most.  The subsequent fights, on the other hand, I've spent hours on, and made little progress in fully beating.  Cave Story absolutely does not prepare you, in any way, for the level of difficulty that comes with these final bosses.

     The fights would absolutely be beatable for if there had been savepoints in between, which again, is how it works for the entirety of the game up to that point.  Giving the player multiple challenging boss fights, with no intervening chance to save, is the kind of offense not even a modern bastion of hard gaming like Dark Souls would commit,  and for most of its playtime, this game is not Dark Souls. 

     And on top of all that, I looked up the ending, and it turns out that after those four fights, there's ANOTHER challenge before the ending, still with no savepoint.  [b] In the ending of this game, it is possible to beat four different bosses, before getting hit on the head with a rock, and having to start all over. [/b]

     I imagine to a certain stripe of gaming masochist out there, this all sounds just great, but again, THIS CAME OUT OF NOWHERE.  Most of the game is not like this.  It's like eating a footlong sub with a single habanero pepper on the end.  Most of the experience is perfectly fine and tasy, and then, out of nowhere, your mouth is on fire.

43410583.review: Ah man I don't even know where to start. This game will always be special to me. I've first discovered it over 10 years ago and played it day and night back in 2008 to figure out all the endings and how to get to the seceret final area...Hell. I was so young back then and I didn't think about looking it up on google lol, but eventually I figured it out. Playing this again was by far the most nostalgic experience I had in a long time, I'll never forget this game. Ok now time to focus on the game itsself: Cave Story was origianlly created by Studio Pixel back in 2004, later this remaster came out on steam in 2011. This remaster is pretty good, the graphic's are redone really well and looks great without ruinning the original style. The music is also redone in two ways: New or remastered. I prefer the original over the new ones however the remastered music is great and I prefer the remastered over the new and original. One other thing that's been changed in the remaster is the dialeuge and the naming, Balrog says "Huzaah!" in the original and not "Oh Yeeah" and also it's "Grasstown" not "Bushlands" etc... That's not all the remaster has to offer, It also has different modes and challenges like the Machinegun Challenge or the Boss Challenge wich are pretty alright I'd say. Then there is Curly Story that's kinda stupid; you basically play the whole story mode as Curly Brace, a girl you later on will meet in the normal story mode. There is a little bit extra dialouge in Curly Story but really not much, you're not missing out on anything by not playing that mode. The whole story takes place on a island floating in the sky. It starts with you waking up in a cave and you can't remember anything. You are a robot that was meant to fight a war on earth. [spoiler] Later you find yourself in a place called Mimiga Village where the creatures called Mimiga lives. Mimiga can be turned into raging killing machines if they eat a substance called "Red Flowers". The main antagonist wants to use the Red Flowers to create an army of Mimiga to attack the surface. [/spoiler] That's a very basic summary of the story I'm not telling the whole thing. Wheather you are completely new to the game or know it for a long time like me, I recommend it to anyone. I had lots of fun playing! The gameplay is great and the story is excellent! One more thing, you don't need to buy the remaster to get the full experience, you can also just download the original 2004 version from the site www.cavestory.org you'll have to download and install the English Translation patch too because the original game is in Japanese, but it's easy to do it and it still works perfectly with windows 10. Keep in mind that the original is only the story, you don't get all the new modes, challenges and of course the new graphics and soundtracks.

42954588.review:
I have no hesitation in saying Cave Story is my favourite video game of all time.

The gameplay is basically rather simple platforming/run'n'gun stuff with some weapons that feel very nice, and get stronger as you gather XP for them from enemies, levelling them up a total of three levels maximum(Though a couple of the secret weapons break this setup in some rather interesting ways), however this can be somewhat fleeting, as you lose XP from your current weapon whenever you take damage.

The story, world, music, art, and characterisation are all very charming. The interesting thing about the story of this game is that you kind of walk into the middle of it in the game, and figure out what's going on as it's already well underway. Without spoiling anything, essentially an evil scientist is kidnapping people from a village of peaceful Mimigas(Cute little bunny people) with the help of an evil witch Mimiga, and a large box man, presumably for the purposes of some evil scheme.
As time goes on, the characters in the story talk about what's going on, and you find out more and more about what exactly is happening in this world, what the mad doctor's evil scheme is, and why you have to stop him.
The characters are endearing, and ultimately, the story really rides on the strength of the subtleties of these characters; pretty much all the principle players have something interesting about them to learn, which gives a greater context for the current events happening in the game.

So, you've got kick-ass platforming gameplay, a really charming story with a lot of depth of character to dig into, some awesome music, and the art is really great. This is already the makings of a classic, but there's more.

The thing about Cave Story is that when I first played it, there were a few small turns the story took in the second half that I didn't like much, and I thought could have been handled better. Then, I found out about the alternate ending. Essentially, if you don't get the jetpack, and then before fighting the boss immediately after the opportunity to get the jetpack, you go into the boss area, and pick up the "Tow rope" item, you trigger a sidequest you pick up on at a couple of points in the game, which ultimately leads to a small hut you walk past just after you've beaten the final boss being open. Inside this hut, you gain access to one final level, which is ridiculously hard, but if you can beat it, you see the alternate "True ending". It took me about a week and a half of solidly playing that and not doing anything else to get through it, but I don't regret a single second of it; it was a really cool final "ridiculously hard gauntlet to prove you're worthy of the real ending" section to send the game off with, and the ending it leads to is far more satisfying than the standard ending, which ties up all the loose ends, and leaves me with nothing really left to say against it...

Well... Actually, there are a few things to say against it.

First off, there's a boss in the Labyrinth where the last checkpoint before it is a good few minutes away from the boss himself, and it's one of the harder bosses in the game, so not only do you have to go all the way back to that checkpoint every time you die, but it's incredibly easy to get hit by enemies on the way, and face the boss while only at half health, or less.

Second, the secret area you have to beat at the end of the alternate ending has one element to it that carries it over from challenging to needlessly obtuse; any time you die in any of the 5 rooms it covers(Including a boss and a mini-boss), you start from the beginning of room 1, and if you happened to be hit by any boxes or anything on your way out to it from the final boss of the standard run, there's no hearts to restore your health until the end of room 2.
I like the fact that the final level is so hard, and I enjoyed trying repeatedly to defeat it, but having to run the entire gauntlet over and over again from the start any time I made a mistake just barely big enough to get me killed(Which isn't hard in this gauntlet; there are a good few instant death pits, and both of the bosses are incredibly difficult) is just needlessly obtuse.

And finally, the way you trigger the alternate ending initially is very obtuse, and I have no idea how anyone is supposed to figure it out without looking it up. There's a section where you see someone fall down a bit that appears to be an impossible jump, which it seems you're supposed to fail to cross and fall down. If you talk to the person who fell, they give you a jetpack, allowing you to get across. Thing is, the jump isn't impossible, and if you time your jump such that you jump just as your character is over a tiny little red marker that you'd never notice unless you randomly decided to wait around in that section for no reason and examine the floor, you can make it over. But, then you have to go into the boss area, walk all the way to the back of it, and pick up an item that's now there thanks to you not getting the jetpack. Then, after you've defeated the boss, you have to use the item, and make your way to a little hut, which is very easy to not get to, as it requires you to jump over a gap that's forcing you across and down into it. There's a couple of yes/no options during this process where effectively one choice can render the whole effort moot, while the other allows the thing to progress(If you're reading this as a guide on how to get the secret ending, and you want me to be a bit more specific, in order to get the secret ending, you have to not leave, and then take it with you). Unless you read an online guide, I have no idea how in the hell you're supposed to know how to do that.

But, that really is it. Three points of frustration I have with it are the only real criticisms I hold against it. I even give that third one some slack due to the fact it stops you from going for the secret ending your first time around(Which is a VERY bad idea. First time around, there's no way you'll be ready for the secret ending). And that's something in general that's pretty neat about the game; your first time around, you'll probably make some non-optimal choices that make the game more suited to the first play-through of a beginner, then the next time you play through, you'll probably do things a little better(For example: Don't get the machine gun, go for the secret ending, get a couple of the secret weapons like the Snake and the Nemesis), though don't feel bad if you can't beat the secret ending on your second, or even third, playthrough.
If you want my advice, on your third playthrough, try to find the secret that trades you the Spur weapon instead of the Polar Star, machine gun, or Snake, get the Whimsical Star secret upgrade for it that replaced the Snake weapon trade, seek out and get every health upgrade(Don't be ashamed of looking them up online if you missed one or two, but do give it the old college try before resorting to that), and don't get the Nemesis weapon. With that, you should be basically optimal. Aside from that, the only advice I can offer is to read the Steam guides on how to beat the secret ending, and watch some speedruns and such; you can find some rather helpful little tricks in those that you may not be able to figure out for yourself.

But anyway, ultimately, this is a really great game, and as you can tell from how much I've written about this while barely scratching the surface, there's a lot of depth to it. And despite the fact there are definitely things I will openly critcise about it, I love this game to bits, and consider it my favourite game of all time.
So, check this one out, you'll probably have a really fun time with it.

42038961.review:
Cave Story +, basic release in 2005, took over colors. Remixer in 2011 and published by Pixel Studio (and Nicalis, INC.) Is one of the best Metroidevania I've played so far.

History: 9/10

This game gives us access to the story of a character called "Quote". This character in question is himself amnesic and does not remember his past. During his quest, he will meet mimigas (rabbits) and other humans, as well as a rather comical rival named Balrog. He later discovered that he was ultimately just a simple surface war robot that had been created by other humans.

Gameplay: 9/10

Cave Story takes exactly all the possible bases of metroidevania: run, jump, shoot, fly, as its description indicates. The highlight of this game is the variety of weapon levels, and improvements to have.

Graphics: 10/10

This game takes exactly the good old graphics of the snes. There is nothing to say, especially since you can play with the graphics of the game retouched OR the original (which is basic free). For an independent company, I only want to say one thing: a nice bravo to the entire team. :)

Soundtrack: 10/10

The music and sounds created by Studio Pixel are quite good. It's hard to say that the soundtrack is horrible, since all the music goes well with the mood of the stage. Frankly, I listen to them even sometimes on youtube.

Summary: 96/100

Cave Story is for me THE metroivania that has never been released (especially since the game dates from over 13 years ago to date, and the remastered 7. If you really want to unleash you, kill mob, improve your weapons, and have a platformer two dimenssions, this game is for you.


PS: It's the only game where you can found Angel in Hell

Histoire: 9/10

Ce jeu nous donne accès à l'histoire d'un personnage appelé "Quote". Ce personnage en question est lui-même amnésique et ne se souvient pas de son passé. Cave Story prend exactement toutes les bases possibles de metroidevania: courir, sauter, tirer, voler, comme l’indique sa description. Le point culminant de ce jeu est la variété des niveaux d'armes et des améliorations à avoir.

Graphisme: 10/10

Ce jeu reprend exactement les bons vieux graphismes de la SNES. As somebody playing this game for the first time in 2018, I can definitely appreciate why Cave Story is still talked about. The story behind it's development is pretty inspiring, and the fact that it handles competently backs it all up. Against this background though, that's all it really ends up being by today's standards: competent. It delivers an admittedly short but warm-hearted story, the variety in the few weapons you get are decent, and the bosses have enough diversity to not feel rinsed and repeated. The platforming is pretty slippery, like some of the retro games it's emulating, which might be a draw for some people but could make certain sections feel like a chore for others.

At the end of the day, this platformer just kind of lost me. I actually ended up opting for the bad ending and streaming the good one, but Cave Story is a piece of indie gaming history, so maybe that warrants the buy on it's own. However, if you are on the fence and you're just scrolling through your wishlist, maybe go back and take a second look.

5/10

41514289.review:
I grudgingly give this a thumbs up.

It's a metroidvania type game that's generally a lot of fun. However, there are some really tedious difficulty spikes in places that drag it down. There's a sequence in particular that is ridiculous, making you face four bosses in a row, with no replenishing health in between.

Seeing as only the first one gives you any health, even if you are full when you finish it there's little chance of keeping it that way for the next three. And they all do quite a  lot of damage. When I got to the last I had one health left! Killing them isn't too hard by themselves, but making it through with enough for the next one, and then the next one, is super annoying.

Most of the game is enjoyable platforming and shooting, but the floaty jumps and pixel precise level design with instant death spikes all over the place are not so enjoyable. Theres an underwater level where currents push you along, and the scrolling is too slow to keep up with your character, so you end up having to memorize where spikes are as its impossible to do it by reflex alone.

It's a pity that it has these bits, as it's pleasant looking, has catchy music and is mostly good to play. These rock hard sequences are a pain though, and after failing for about the twentieth time on this last boss I'm not feeling very forgiving!  It just about scrapes a positive review, though I'd happily have knocked off an hour or two of the play time, given that its bloated by this wonky challenge in places.

41470055.review:
Cave Story+ has all the right ingredients for a solid indie game. Its visual design is both unique and charming; its gunplay is enjoyable with some rather engaging boss fights; its story is simple yet engaging with a colorful cast of characters; all the while featuring a wonderfully-composed soundtrack.

But I still can't recommend it.

I wanted to like this game. I really did. I was genuinely having fun with it very early on. Unfortunately, there's a lot of minor design decisions that are so numerous and significant they broke the experience for me.

For starters, some of the levels expect a lot of back and forth from the player, imposed through arbitrary mechanical limitations that don't make a lot of sense (why can you only carry one jam jar?). This normally wouldn't be an issue if the level design was good enough, which sadly isn't the case. I'd even go out of my way to say the level design is horrendous. Now Cave Story doesn't have the tightest platforming; the main character jumps far too high to be able to effectively judge where he'll land, and he maintains enough momentum to slip off ledges after landing, even if the player isn't pushing a certain direction. This is only made worse by how the game expects quite a lot of precise platforming to maneuver around, with usually only one way to climb up and reach the series of tiles you need to jump across. If you miss a jump, you have to go back to the very beginning of the queue, and some of these do stretch quite far.

It doesn't help that the game respawns enemies all the time, and considering how vital it is to avoid getting hit in order to maintain your weapons' efficiency, you'll often be locked into fighting these enemies again every time you want to cross, back and forth. There's also no efficient shortcuts to unlock after traversing certain areas, and all this does is add to the tedium when better time could be spent on either more interesting things or making the game shorter (which I'll get into why it needed this later). The game also really likes setting instant-death traps, and although save points aren't too far apart, everything else I explained makes them feel like they are, so any accidental slip off the edge because of the game's awkward platforming can be pretty frustrating. Usually these instant-death traps wouldn't be a big deal if the player could traverse screens quickly and efficiently; a prime example of that being implemented well from recent memory being in Shovel Knight, which also has a robust enough platforming system where deaths often do not feel cheap.

Things escalated to a point that I had to traverse a location in the game back and forth five times and once more forwards at minimum because I could only carry one dog at a time, with the sixth time forwards being so as to cross over to the next objective. It's kind of a shame because there are a couple of points in the game where the level design is honestly clever, but so much of it is ignored by the sheer volume of bizarre designs in a majority of the game.

Another big issue comes in the form of how the game is structured towards the end. It's often recommended for new players to go with either the bad or neutral ending first, with the good ending being reserved for second-time players or veterans. What determines the ending you end up with all happens around the end of the second act of the game. If you do want to go for the true ending, there are a lot of choices you need to make, some of which could be a little arbitrary that would require the player to read some sort of walkthrough, or be physically difficult to do. It doesn't help that picking the true ending makes the game significantly more challenging, and sadly the cheap kind of challenging. The worst being in [spoiler]Final Cave where for some arbitrary reason, you lose all the chips you accumulated for your guns, bringing them all back to LV1, meaning that you either have to farm the local enemies to get them back up, or you try to get past that stage the way you are, and it is not easy especially with the sudden difficulty spike where you now have to platform using a jetpack (that can be clunky to use especially if you need to fly and shoot in two different directions). The game additionally adds an extra boss that is genuinely fun as it is tough considering that level, but unfortunately leaves a hidden instant-death trap immediately after the combat arena that.[/spoiler] It was here where I just gave up; I had so many other games to play, and having to throw myself at a part of a game that feels unsatisfying and cheap was not worth it. I also hear that the true ending [spoiler]adds an incredibly optional yet challenging boss fight[/spoiler] past that point which I would have loved to have thrown myself at but sadly I won't get the chance to do so.

None of this would have mattered as much as it did if the game had a robust save system. It doesn't sadly. You get three save slots, and you're locked to the save slot you chose for the entirety of the run. In a game where you could easily mess up your choices, being given the option to handle multiple save slots would mean you could skip a lot of the early tedium and jump right to the branching decision in order to progress towards the different endings after completing a playthrough, without having to replay the entire game from scratch, through a lot of the annoying platforming. Heck, if this game was much shorter and the more tiresome aspects that are there to extend playtime were removed, I would have been totally fine with replaying the game from the beginning each time.

Although I did praise the bosses in this game, some of them feel a little too easy simply because their patterns were far too predictable. I suppose it really shows how this was originally a free indie game from 2004.

In conclusion, Cave Story+ has a lot of good going for it, but so many tiny little design details can easily turn people off, and sadly I was one of those people. Although I do appreciate the upgrades this version brings, it still desparately needed more for some of its gameplay issues, which is apparently the case for Cave Story++ on the Nintendo Switch. Maybe that version fixes a majority of my complaints and that would be the one to get, but I can't say for sure. What the developer (Pixel) has done is a wonderful job especially with the original, but...you really should have tested the game a lot more, man.

Alright so...
First off, I know it says 1.5 hours on my record here but I've played this a ton on the 3DS with Cave Story and Cave Story 3D, then recently with Cave Story+ on Nintendo Switch.
Since that's outta the way let's get into this review.

Cave Story has to be one of my favorite games in the platforming genre mostly because the music, story, characters... everything is just amazing. And theres so many ports and iterations of it that it's just like wow, look at this. This was an indie game before indies were a thing. One guy made this game and it blew up to be one of the best games in an action platformer style game.

Story is fairly simple but very very complex at the same time, and I really can't talk about this because I really don't want to slip, go into spoiler territory and mess it up for anyone new to this game. But just trust me when I say this story makes it worth the trouble and difficulty this game gives you (unless you're playing on easy, like me. (and even then getting the best/true ending will be tough for you! I've yet to get it even though I know what happens.)

Gameplay is floaty but DEFINITELY POLISHED. It reminds me of a mix of OG Megaman and NES Metroid (Nestroid as people like to call it) and it definitely shows in different aspects. You explore like Metroid, you get weapons that are kinda like how weapons work in Megaman- But I digress, this is its own thing and it really deserves recognition of being its own thing.

Anyway I really don't want to talk much more about this game because I'm afraid of spoiling it so how about you do like I did, take the word of a stranger and give this game a try! You won't be disappointed (ESPECIALLY if its on sale!!!!!)

The Switch version is actually a bit better and hope they patch the PC version soon with the additions it has such as 2 new soundtracks to play with, new challenges in the challenge mini game thing, face portraits actually blink and move and talk n whatnot, and if you find a first run of it physically you get an actual full color manual, a sound track CD with some of the tracks from the first of 2 new sound tracks, the Famitrack! But anyway, this version is the closest to the complete version you can find and I'm sure it'll be updated with the Cave Story+content that the Switch got because this is the PC version after all.

The thing is that Cave Story on Steam has a "+" for a reason and it has more content, is more polished and clean, etc. But yeah, I figure I'd put that out for anyone who wants to try it first as a sort of demo.

41152743.review:
I've always had a love and hate relationship with this game, to be honest.

On one hand it's a solid Metroid like 2D platformer/shooter with quirky aesthetics and a really good chiptune soundtrack. The game is short enough to do a full run in one sitting whenever you feel bored and want some old school action. Each playthrough can be very different depending on what choices you make throughout the game. There are multiple difficulty modes, mutually exclusive weapon loadouts, secret and alternative levels and bosses.

On the other hand, there are some questionable design decisions. The cutscenes are not only unskippable but you have to press and hold a button to manually advance through every sentence being said. Some of the backtracking is really tedious and breaks the pace of the game. The checkpoint starvation becomes less of a problem as you "git gud" at the game but can still feel a bit too punishing if you accidentally slip up and have to redo the whole level from scratch.

The Steam version is only slightly better than the original freeware release. It includes 2x upscaled graphics, 2 remixed soundtracks, some extra levels to play outside of the main story and quite a few achievements to collect. Unfortunately it doesn't support widescreen or any aspect ratio other than the original 4:3. If you want to play Cave Story in 16:9 I'd recommend getting either the open source version (NXEngine-evo) or the PSP port (through the PPSSPP emulator). Both are completely free and legal.

41119411.review: Kind of a shallow story experience, but overall fun.

40889313.review:
Short version:
Should you buy this game: No. You can get it for free online, and this version doesn't add enough to the experience to warrant buying.

Should you play this game: Yes. It is a challenging and rewarding game. But I have to add the caveat that you should use a guide. Not to make the game easier, but because the "best ending" would be almost impossible to get without being told where to go at what times.

Longer version:
This game starts out fine. Tight controls, okay platforming, decent weapons, quirky world, and one of the most important things, it forces you to get better at it. It becomes more challenging at a relatively acceptable pace.

The first big problem comes at the start of the second level (the desert one). You can switch your main weapon for a machine gun. It wasn't very long before I realised that when upgraded fully, the machine gun can propel you into the air. [b]This is a major problem[/b]. It breaks the entire design of the game, where you are meant to carefully platform in certain areas, you can instead use the machine gun to fly over enemies' heads and get straight  to the end. I can't emphasize how much this ruins the experience of the game, because I didn't even think to realise I was playing the game wrong until halfway through the next area.

I will come back to the problem of platforming later.

The next problem was the requirements to get the proper ending. This begins at the end of the third area. Avoiding spoilers, you are given a clear story cue, but to get the best ending, you have to, with no good reason, ignore the cue, and make an almost impossible jump. Then you have to get an item you have no good reason to find, and jump through a number of other hoops, just to unlock the possibility of reaching the best ending. Then, you have to go into some random little room when you should be running away from something to find the last level.

You are not given an indication that you should do [b]any[/b] of these things, and if you miss one of them and then save your game, then you can't go back and fix them. You have to start the game again.

Now, back to the platforming: There is a large platforming section near the end of the game (outer wall), at which point you will have one kind or another of rocket boots. This platforming area would be among the peak of game design that this game has to offer, and it almost seems to be made with normal platforming in mind, but so much of it is simply destroyed by the player's ability to fly past it. The addition of the boosters to the game should reshape all of the levels following, but it ends up destroying them.

Now, if you do somehow get the requirements for the end, you are met with two levels that make full use of the game mechanics: [spoiler]last cave[/spoiler] and [spoiler]blood-stained sanctuary[/spoiler]. These are challenging and rewarding, and really the best the game has to offer. The problem is that there's no difficulty curve. These are the only parts of the game that make proper use of the booster, so when you get to the latter, you are pretty much dropped in the deep-end and have to be extremely patient. I completed this game twice, once with the basic endings and once with the best ending, and [spoiler]blood-stained sanctuary[/spoiler] took more than a third of my total playtime to complete, chipping away at it an hour or two at a time. (Note: The actual level only took maybe 10 minutes to complete, it was just the number of attempts that added up)

There are some more minor things in this game that I think could be improved, like perhaps an autosave system, or just some better save-point placement to make the game's structure more clear.

I'm certain there is more I've missed or forgotten, but I will move on to the rest of the game.

The pixel art is all very nice, fitting a consistent aesthetic, and the world is quirky and interesting. The characters are nothing to write home about, and the story is serviceable (bad guy is going to do bad things, better stop him), although one of the endings contains nothing short of a deus ex machina, which the characters then kinda acknowledge...? It's strange. The music was fairly good for a one-man project, even charming, but I think it's a tad overhyped. Finally, the translation. The game is originally Japanese, and in this version of the game, it shows in places. There are times when the text just comes across as... clunky. Not quite right. I'm told the free translation is different though.

In summary, Cave Story is a good game, and definitely deserves a playthrough, but it is not a great game.

40623338.review: I have replayed this game well over 30 times, bought it 3 times on different consoles, and enjoyed every moment of the 300+ hours I've put into it. The replay value for this game is that high. What started out as a project one man worked on in his free time has become possibly the most well known and critically acclaimed indie games of all time, as well as one of my personal favorite games of all time, and Nicalis' remake of it makes it all the better. Between the fun gameplay, colorful characters, great story, the astounding HD remake graphics for a game that uses 16 bit sprites and arguably the best part of the game, the remastered soundtrack, Cave Story is truly the king of indie games, and is perfect in every way imaginable.

40600624.review:
I had a love affair with this game in college and revisited it once a fellow fan told me about the Steam release. 

It's a platformer that pulls wonderfully from Mega Man and Contra with the added flourish of Bethesda/Bioware storytelling, where so many decisions in the game can drastically alter the path of the story. The beloved characters and beautiful classic pixel art make some of these choices all the more heartbreaking when the time to decide.

The learning curve starts a bit sharp, but if you put some extra time into the early levels, you'll get the hang of the weapon swaps and leveling system. Getting hit definitely punishes hard, but it's designed to have more retro punishing mechanics. 

Big fan, take a weekend and enjoy the ride.

P.S. [spoiler]There are a bunch of hidden dungeons and items along with those story choices. Find them if you can...[/spoiler]

40598062.review: This is a very special game. I saw the art style, and expected to not like it. After hearing from multiple sourcing that it was actually good, I caved in and played it. The gameplay is fun, the soundtrack is well above average, the platforming is good, the story is better anything else I've played in the genre, and the art grows on you. It's so clearly the product of one person's vision, and brings a wholly unique, yet cohesive style. This game is actually from 2004, yet you would never know from playing it. I have much more than my recorded 9.7 hours playing this game on other versions elsewhere. I still have yet to beat the secret final boss, but maybe one day I will. I would wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone willing to give it a shot.

First, my complaints:

- I hate the floaty physics and after a couple playthroughs, I never did get used to it. I lost track of how many times I died because I missed a jump I normally wouldn't have. 

- The way the screen/"camera" moves with you is a bit annoying. 

- The screen shake during the final boss was so out of control that I constantly lost track of where I was on the screen. Add the "camera" movement and floaty physics to that and you have a final boss that is 10x more frustrating that it should have been. 

- If you're a Metroidvania nut like me, you might be a bit disappointed by the exploration. The game is a lot more linear than I expected. There's very few times where going back to previous areas is actually necessary or recommended. 

That said, I did enjoy the game. There are a few choices you can make that drastically change how things will go. After the normal ending path, I thought the game was just okay. I did the best ending path immediately afterwards and decided that I actually really liked the game. 

Overall, I'm glad I played it and I'll most likely come back to it when I'm on an achievement spree.

Ah, uno de los mejores en el genero Metroidvania que podrias encontrar alli afuera. Ese es Cave Story.

El juego es simple: Tomas un arma, saltas y disparas en 4 direcciones a cual sea el pobre sujeto que se meta en frente con un arsenal variado, entre cohetes, lasers y espadas lanzables.

Los enemigos son numerosos y algunos bastante duros o muy dedicados a joderte la vida, pero no suelen ser muy complicados.

El plataformeo es uno de los puntos mas fuertes del juego, creeme, en ciertas partes la pasaras mal, pero si que es una experiencia.

Los bosses definitivamente son un reto, eso, si te dejas intimidar por ellos.

El lore no es lo mas asombroso en comparacion a los demas puntos, pero no se queda atras en lo absoluto. 

El ost... Es sencillamente maravilloso, acompaña perfectamente el ambiente de los niveles y las batallas en los bosses, especialmente la batalla final... Es sencillamente excelente.

La dificultad... Es complicado, pero no tan dificil... Claro a menos que quieras entrar en el modo Hard... Pasaras un MUY mal rato, especialmente en cierta cueva y en adelante... pero si te sientes confiado en ello, podras sacarle el 100% al jugo del juego, una experiencia de dificultad que no se encuentra todos los dias.

Los retos por fuera son un gran agregado al juego, especialmente Wind fortress y El boss rush.

En resumen: Este juego fue el ''Punto de inflexion'' en los juegos indie, ya que cuando salio su version original muchos hablaban del mismo y motivo a otros a meterse en el desarrollo de juegos indie. En este caso, esta remasterizacion grafica y con contenido extra es sencillamente perfecta. Todo se mezcla perfectamente entre si en este juego. 9.5/10

39291285.review: One of the best free games out there that I have willingly paid money for; I originally downloaded Daisuke Amaya's lovingly crafted action platformer for free and had a difficult but fulfilling experience making it through my first run. Afterward, I replayed it to get the various other endings and found myself in a much more difficult but all the more fulfilling adventure each time. I bought the Steam version mostly for the Curly Brace version and enjoyed it immensely, though my nostalgia for the original English translation did make me wish it was availiable as an option in this version. Cave Story is an excellent game with a memorable story, compelling characters, challenging levels and bosses, a unique weapon system, a beautiful soundtrack, and so much replayability that I can't even remember how many times I've gone through the Steam version much less the original. 39093777.review:
The gameplay leeches the fun out of a game that, otherwise, showed a lot of promise and polish.

Control Method: XBOX One Controller
Difficulty: Hard (brings out the best and the worst in a game)

Gameplay:
Character momentum onset is too sudden, and direction cannot be easily changed in air, which leads to many unintended collisions with terrain and opponents. Small joystick deadzone leads to unintended changes in direction during critical combat maneuvers. Weapon trajectories are too constrained or haphazard, leaving the player to attempt many cumbersome jump shots using the aforementioned unfavorable movement physics.

No autosave feature, which at times prevented story-advancing dialogue or sequences from occuring between deaths. Dialogue-intense cutscenes cannot be skipped ever. Some parts of the game become tedious bullet hells (in hard mode, nearly everything is a 1-hit kill).

Story:
Nothing too compelling, but some of the darker themes of death and physical abuse clash poignantly with the fun, cartoon art style. In general, it is whimsical, with hints of bipolar disorder.

Presentation:
Retro pixellated style was rendered very nicely, and is probably the most attractive prospect of Cave Story.

Miscellany:
Seasonal art always has to be toggled on/off at the start of the game or the wrong sprites load.
You're supposed to find someone's panties in order to unlock a new game mode. Typical Japanese awkwardness.
The villain has a face that I desperately want to punch.

Summary:
Don't buy into the hype, unless it's on sale or your friends bully you into getting it. Don't play on hard mode unless you are either incredibly skilled, masochistic, or both.

Goodbye.

39093526.review:
Clocking in at about 6 hours, Cave Story is an action platformer when you jump around shooting stuff.

Gameplay: 6/10

The game's core pillar is solely combat, with weak exploration and level design.

Its combat is merely serviceable.

You have access to a variety of guns that do different things. Some guns are hidden away and unlocked through completing side-objectives.

Shooting is functional. The guns had no impact and didn't feel fun to shoot. Thankfully, the different weapons you had access to (I unlocked 5) all played different enough roles that enjoyment was gained in deciding which gun was best fit in the situation I found myself in.

There is also an interesting system where you level up your guns as you collect experience from killing baddies. When you get injured, not only does your health go down, but your gun level goes down too. I felt that this was an unnecessary system as it double penalized the player for making mistakes; if the player wasn't doing well, they would be stuck in a vicious cycle where their guns would remain weak and end up not having fun with the higher levelled guns.

The baddies themselves also aren't that great. While they are good aesthetically, and each section comes with its own visually distinctive enemies, mechanically speaking they only come in two flavors: a melee type which charges/flies at you, and a ranged type which throws projectiles at you. Both injure you on contact. That's it. Disappointing to be honest. AM2R (Metroid) had such a large variety of enemies, many having a twist in how you take them down (not just shooting at them), whilst having other gameplay pillars to support it (good ones, mind you).

The controls are also pretty bad; your character feels super floaty, and the jetpack ability you get halfway through the game also feels incredibly awkward to control. I did however discover that you could send yourself up by shooting your machinegun downwards, which was a pleasant surprise and a great addition.

In game where shooting enemies is its core engagement, and shooting isn't fun, makes for a poor game.

Graphics: 7/10

I played Cave Story+, on Steam, which provides HD versions of its original pixel art aesthetic. Its good, but not amazing either.

I quite appreciated that there were Christmas and Halloween reskins of every tile, many enemies, and almost every character, that activated during particular times of the month. I myself played through most of the game in Christmas mode and it was a treat. Plus points here for such a cool feature.

Story: 4/10

As one half of the game's name, Cave Story /attempts/ to tell an interesting narrative. Unfortunately, the game's short game length meant that characters I was just introduced to end up getting killed of an hour or two later—deaths which lacked any sort of emotional punch. Slight spoilers, but these deaths happened more than twice.

It also sets up an interesting universe that I am intrigued to learn more of, but unfortunately other than the critical path, no lore nuggets are present in the game. You only get to experience the main story (and an optional, bonus ending if you go through "hell mode"). The game's main antagonists, their backstory or their motivations, are barely expanded upon, and overall I feel there were too many weak narrative threads.

There is also a crucial character that can be killed off if you fail a particular jump. In my playthrough I had no idea that the jump I missed was so crucial to the story, only discovering it when I browsed the wiki. Such a easily fail-able challenge resulting in the player skipping a huge narrative thread is unacceptable. Perhaps it was to encourage replayability, but the game's mediocre combat system means I will disappointingly not be doing so.

AM2R is a great example of telling a story through its world and the places you explore. Cave Story attempts to beat you on the head with a narrative that is neither compelling nor well-explained. Another game which I am playing through right now, Ubisoft's Child of Light, is also a better example of telling a short but strong narrative without beating you over the head over it.

Sound: 8/10

The game's soundtrack is stupendous and the game's redeeming quality. It's great. Just check out the title screen music and you'll love it.

However, the sound design for stuff like your guns is weak, and sound effects for stuff like enemies is non-existent.

Overall, Cave Story was an interesting experience. As one of the few "good" indie games of the 2000-2010 decade, I am sure it left its mark on the industry. Comparing it to AAA-produced titles like Konami's Castlevania is of course unfair, but I feel that this game is vastly inferior to the past 5 titles I have played in my trip through platformer history. Still, it marks a good transition to the golden age of indies from 2010 onwards, and I will be playing a few of these (platformer) titles next.

I rate Cave Story 6/10.

A mediocre story, with serviceable gunplay, but a good soundtrack. Its most definitely a modern game, and I did get some fun out of it. But its not noteworthy. Is it worth $15? Maybe. But there are better offerings out there. Try Shovel Knight for a guaranteed excellent platformer.

Se trata de un metroidvania (mapa enorme interconectado por puertas que iremos abriendo después de hablar con cierto personaje o adquirir cierto objeto) con énfasis en las plataformas y la acción, no es complicado si tenemos práctica en este tipo de juegos pero como la exploración es necesaria, hay que tener paciencia e incluso algo de suerte para no atascarnos y perder el tiempo dando vueltas. La historia está a la altura, es decir, suficientemente interesante pero no densa para no aburrir y restarle a la acción, y las conversaciones son siempre escuetas, pero conviene atender a cada diálogo ya que nos orientan hacia donde debemos ir o hacer. Las armas son variadas y van mejorando, además si nos golpean mucho pierden eficacia por lo que estaremos atentos a tenerlas siempre al máximo. Muy recomendable jugarlo con mando.

Si le busco puntos negativos, los enemigos se regeneran después de regresar a una zona, eso hace que el juego no sea un paseo pero cansa cuando necesitas explorar zonas ya visitadas, especialmente cuando andas perdido. Los puntos de guardado están bien repartidos pero siempre tienen esa pega de hacernos repetir alguna pantalla o tener que volver a buscar un objeto.

Divertido de principio a fin, con una curva de aprendizaje excelente, muchos tipos de personaje, enemigos con una dificultad ajustada, objetos que nos darán habilidades nuevas, una banda sonora destacable y gráficos al estilo 16 bits. Se siente un juego muy cuidado.

38446154.review:
Cave Story is one of my favorite games of all time, but I do not at all recommend this remake, especially on Mac or Linux.

Technical issues:
- No Steam cloud saves
- Broken achievements (Impossible to get 100% without editing files)
- Only 3 save files
- Game uses a crash to exit from challenges menu
- DOES NOT START ON MANY LINUX MACHINES, NO FIX AVAILABLE
- Even if you do get it to start on Linux, achievements apparently don't work (couldn't test this because I couldn't get the game to start on Linux. Windows was fine)

These problems have been broken for years, with no hope of being fixed.

Personal Gripes as a gamer and a die-hard Cave Story fan:
- "enhanced" graphics add nothing
- New soundtracks are not good (though since the original is an option having options is good)
- Part of the magic of Cave Story is that it was created by a single person (Pixel) and released for free. This remake feels like a corruption of Pixel's original ideals
- No Balrog "Huzzah!" (Not really a big deal)

The original version is 100% FREE and will get you a more pure, authentic, and enjoyable experience in my opinion. If you want to support Pixel, there are other avenues to do so, such as by buying Kero Blaster on Steam.

38404573.review:
There it is. The game that probably started the whole "retro-styled" indie game avalanche. That doesn't mean the game is bad though. Let's bring the checklist.
Music - the original soundtrack was already good, and the remastered version makes it even better, with some of the tracks like Running Hell or Jenka 1 being in my personal top 10.
Graphics - again, the original was good (although a little bland) and the remaster is better, reminding me of 2D PSX games.
Gameplay - it seems the new ver didn't need to change much. The controls are responsive and tight. The aerial momentum doesn't suit me, but that could be just my opinion.
No game is without its flaws, and it's obvious this one has a bunch too. For example, i felt the Grasslands world is a little bit too repetitive, going through the same enemy nest 5 times. Difficulty spikes are present too, (although not in great amounts). Perhaps Monster X and Dragon Sisters could be the best example, being hell for most newcomers, like me.
Also, if you want to achieve the best ending, prepae to follow a lot of strict rules to do it. It's not fun.
All and all, this game is great, as I said before. A solid experience and 10+ hours well spent.

8,5/10

Finales alternos, una dificultad variada, buen control, secretos por descubrir y muchos lugares por explorar son algunas de los elementos que me gustaron mucho de este juego y que me recuerdan a títulos muy divertidos de la época pasada de los videojuegos.

Cave Story es un juego de aventura y exploración con un poco de humor en  sus diálogos; esta es una versión retocada con nueva música y modos de juego (los cuales no he probado aun) pero mantiene la esencia original del juego. 

Eres un robot que despierta sin recordar quien es o donde está y que hace ahí, debemos ayudar a una especie de criaturas tipo conejos muy simpáticos que están siendo amenazados y capturados por un malvado científico loco. 

A lo largo de la aventura encontramos una variedad de armas, ítems, portales y personajes que nos mantendrá siempre curioseando más y más. Este juego es en verdad fascinante, si te gustan los juegos retro de disparar y saltar por ahí haciéndola del héroe te lo recomiendo ampliamente.

Las batallas contra los jefes son divertidas y se convierten en verdaderos desafíos conforme avanza la historia, tiene algunos secretos basados en hablar con los personajes, no he encontrado todo ni siquiera el final bueno. Pero todavía me quedan ganas de jugarlo.

Lo que me gusto:
Tiene pequeños detalles que resaltan como el letrero con un disquete encima de las puertas donde hay acceso para guardar la partida, bloques falsos que permiten accesos diversos, obtener 3 finales distintos, el subir el nivel de las armas, evolucionarlas o canjearlas incluso.

Lo malo o que no me gusto:
Que aquí solo está en inglés (Steam)
El fastidio de volver a ver los diálogos cada que mueres porque no grabaste antes y moriste antes de alguna conversación.  [Me encantaría un botón de Skip o saltar dialogo]
El mapa en pantalla es pequeñísimo casi un chiste su existencia aunque la verdad no es escencial.

*Recomiendo usar joystick.

38024660.review:
[h1]Almost Good, Utterly Generic[/h1]

While not a bad game by any stretch, Cave Story + is not especially exciting either. Bugs, blandness, and an overall lack of polish make this one hard to recommend..

The story has to do with some unexplained war, an 'ancient evil awakens', and amnesia. This unfolds through a series of little cut scenes sprinkled throughout the game. As the player progress more is revealed through character dialogue and a few events, such as before and after a boss battle. There were a few moments that were kind of amusing, but the story here is pretty weak, and often generic.

Game wise the action is never more than decent. Shoot, jump, swim, and navigate your way through a small but diverse set of locations, find some secrets, and really just explore. Most weapons are standard; blaster with three levels of power,Super Mario style bouncing fireballs, missiles, charge beam, etc. Upgradable versions help keep things balanced, such as a sword that unleashes a rapidly striking ghost, or the aforementioned charge beam. A few weapons are actually pretty cool, if a bit overpowered for the most part, which helps cut some of the monotony down.

Speaking of monotony, this game tends to be really tedious. Backtracking and fetch quests take up the bulk of the player's time, along with sometimes painfully slow dialogue boxes. You can't skip the dialogue, which can get really frustrating because most f it is forgettable, boring, or just bad, and if you’ve messed up and need to restart you have to sit through those big chunks of dialogue all over again. It can be really frustrating.

There is a lot of okay level design, but it is, mostly very plain and uninspired. You get big empty chasms with platforms, or narrow hallways with platforms. I felt a strong sense of atmosphere from the floating island of talking dogs. For whatever faults I felt playing this game, this sense of atmosphere and presentation gave me a sense of nostalgia, particularly for the old days of Super Nintendo and Sega Genesis era gaming. Points to the designer for accomplishing this, it's just a shame more wasn't done with it. What we get is a lot of potential, but not a lot of very exciting execution.

Controls are okay, but not especially tight with a game pad, which is a shame because some of what is needed to win will take precision that just isn't there without a keyboard. Using both a PS3 controller and an Xbox One controller, I found that often the left and right movements would stall or not respond properly. For some of the trickier extra stages, like Blood Stained Sanctuary, I found myself depending heavily on the arrow keys despite spending a lot my time trying to make it work on the d-pad.

The soundtracks are pretty good, very reminiscent of 16bit era platforming games, with three versions of the game's score to choose from in the options menu. Graphical options are pretty sparse, but this isn't really a bad thing as the game's styles really are pretty good at helping set the tone.

Overall this looks and behaves like a classic 16bit era game, but with only really basic level and quest design elements. Visually this is mediocre, but serviceable. Some might say that it is important to take the age of the game into consideration, but SNES games were doing a lot of what's in this game long before this came out, and they were doing it better. Still, this is an impressive effort despite its lackluster parts.

It is worth mentioning that some bugs linger, and since this game is not longer supported by the developers you will have to take it “AS IS”. This includes the buggy controls, crashes, a broken achievement (with a user made fix), and other quirks.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Atmosphere
    [*]Music is decent
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Annoying dialogue
    [*]Heavy backtracking
    [*]Bland story
    [*]Lame level design
    [*]Tedious game play
    [*]Boring graphics
    [*]Unreliable controls
    [*]Unfixed bugs
    [*]Not developer supported
    [*]Doesn't always play nice with D-pads
[/list]

[b]Verdict: 4/10[/b]

I've played this game several times over the years, and every time the words 'boring' and 'overrated' came to mind. This isn’t a bad game, but it's just too generic and frustratingly tedious to be all that exciting.
